One point worth making is that describing the SBB as the Swiss railway network is a little misleading and can cause confusion. While the SBB (Swiss Federal Railways) has by far the largest rail network and is regarded as Switzerland's national railway operator, there are a multitude of other operators both large and small. You'll especially find that if you venture onto the mountain railways they're all private operators, as are light rail operators like the Forchbahn (Zürich's S18 line). Some of these operators have extensive networks, such as the combined network of the Matterhorn-Gotthard-Bahn and the Rhätische Bahn - most famous as the route of the Glacier Express.   
However - don't worry about it! With a very few exceptions your half-fare card or GA is valid on pretty much anything that runs on rails. Just don't be put off or confused when you find yourself looking at a train or a station that doesn't have SBB branding.

Hello everyone, I have been stalking on this forum for a few years and have gleaned lots of good information; thanks for that. I would like to give back by providing recent information about my experience importing a used car into Switzerland.   
In summary, I would say it is not worth importing a used car unless it is in tip-top shape and you got a really good deal on it, or it is perhaps a very pricey car that is close to new and selling for a good price. You need to do all the research on import costs and consider the extra hassle and decide if the savings is worth that hassle. There are definite risks of importing an older car: it may not pass a smog (Abgas) test or it may not pass inspection (MFK), resulting in repairs which may be too costly to fix, leaving you stuck with a customs bill and no legal car.   
This post,  , has some good information but was originated several years ago, so I thought I would update with my experience.   
My friend in Germany wanted to sell his mother's car (she is too old to be driving), a 1998 Audi A4. That's right, I said 1998! It was banged up a little bit because her driving skills had degraded to an almost dangerous point. However, it had passed the German fitness test within the past year and my friends had made sure it was functionally taken care of (regardless of the remaining body dings!), and it had winter tires included. I spent some time evaluating whether it would even be worth it to import it since there would be additional effort and cost. In my observation, Swiss used cars are reasonably priced and you can get them with MFK, snow tires, etc. so you can avoid extra hassles.   
What made me go with the buying the Audi is that they only were charging 500. I did a preliminary cost estimate as follows: 
Car: 500 
Certificate of Conformity:  100 
Import Tax 12%: 60 
Import Duty (12-15 chf per 100kg): 120 
Swiss Import Administration fee: 20 
MFK & Emissions test: 150 
Total Estimate: 950 
I used euros for simplification even when the figures came in CHF. It was only an estimate and the exchange rate was not far from parity at the time.   
Some facts in my favor: I was allowed by my friend to take the car with the owner's German plates and was covered by their insurance during the import process. Normally, the buyer may have to obtain temporary export plates from Germany at an additional cost. If you do so, allow plenty of time of plate duration, say 3-4 weeks for the entire process. Temporary insurance would also be then required. I thought originally that I might need it, but my Swiss agent could not help me obtain any. I stopped looking for it when I found I would be covered with the car's German insurance. I also had to consider the export process out of Germany, and my research showed if the car was 500 or less and less than 1,000 kg I would be exempt from a written declaration. My German language skills are at the beginner level so I decided to have my German friend check. He was told by customs that no paperwork is required when a car is exported as a result of a private sale.   
For the Certificate of Conformity, I picked up this site,  , from this forum. However my German friend researched and found out I could go directly to VW (controls Audi now) to get the CoC for a lower cost. I went to that site and ordered the CoC - and it was free! I could only speculate why...perhaps because it was an older car.   
Next, we tried to get a EUR.1 certificate, which exempts us from the import duty, but we gave up after hitting dead ends. Perhaps this is where a dealer can do a better job.   
Also an import declaration is required. This must be done electronically at   which is not available  in English. I used Google Chrome to help me translate. If you abhor forms, you may want to skip this part and use a customs broker. I am not sure how to find one and I have heard they can cost 150 and up even for a simple import. I was able to fill out the form with the required info but their system would not accept it. However, their car import process video explained it could be done onsite, so I decided to do that.   
Finally we were ready to take the car across the border. We chose Waldshut/Koblenz as the car was coming from that area and that is a well-staffed border. It was a little tricky finding the right place to take the car to, but we finally got there. It helped that my wife speaks good German. We then went to the customs desk, armed with these papers: 
- Contract of Sale (found one online in German) 
- Certificate of Conformity 
- Import Declaration filled out, but not yet certified 
- German vehicle registration (2 different documents, a small and a large) 
- Personal identification   
Since the import declaration had not been certified, they directed us to a computer down the hallway that we could use. I went through the same process I had done online but could not get the darn thing to go through! My wife grabbed a customs guy in the hallway, and explained to him that we were having trouble. He quickly looked at it, fiddled with it, and also could not get the system to accept it. He was going on a break, so he asked one of his co-workers to help. He also struggled with it (mentioning in the meantime that they are not required to help us) and finally figured out the system did not like such a low sales value for a car! He was suspicious of the value also, even though we explained it was old and dinged up. "Doesn't matter", he said. He did some more machinations on the form and voila, it went through. Then they printed it out. We still needed one  more thing, a stamp from German customs (just across the hallway) indicating we had indeed exported the car. Got that, then the administrative processor also questioned the value of the car (they like higher, of course) but her supervisor said that it was not unreasonable given the age of the car. Paperwork got finished, then on to pay tax and duties. Tax was as expected but duties were much higher because I made an error on the weight of the car (info from the wrong box of the German registration). The extra cost of duties was balanced out by the free CoC. First major step done! The car now was fully imported.   
Next, we needed to get a smog (Abgas) test. The price varies widely, per my research. Likely because this need is fading, with newer cars using On-board diagnostics for real-time emissions monitoring, acceptable by the Swiss in lieu of an Abgas test. I found a place that would do it for $75, which matched my research. It turned out to be $125 because they claimed the older cars like mine go through a two stage test, plus they had to get a new Agbas test booklet, which my car never needed before, not ever being Swiss. I paid and was happy that part was successful.   
Last was the MFK test. I was able to arrange the appointment after uploading some required documents online to Strassenverkehrsamt Zurich. I was given an appointment for about one week after. I was really nervous about this one. After reading forum posts here with horror stories of clean cars claimed to be dirty and nitpicking inspectors with bad moods, I was expecting the worst. We cleaned up the car inside and out best that we could, and there were no fluid leaks to raise a red flag. We drove in 10 minutes ahead of the appointed time, and they took us right away. They put us on the lift, banged around underneath and swiveled the steering back and forth. Then it was on to the shaking machine and the light testing room. After that, the tester took over the driving and I got in the back seat. He quickly mentioned, in German, that he noticed alot of rust but nothing was rusted through, and he would likely pass the car. He then drove the car on their test track like a bat out of hell and then slammed on the brakes. We were still alive, so I guess we passed that part! He finally worked up the last of the paperwork, mentioning that in his opinion the car may not make it through another test in 2 years or so. Overall he was not as thorough as I expected him to be, though I was glad the car was ready. We took all the paperwork to the exit desk, signed a release on the German plates (since we were giving them back directly to the original owner) and were given a new Swiss registration document. I had kept the plates from my last car and brought them with me to complete the changeover. However, the plate holders on the car were for German plates, which are a different size. No problem, just put the Swiss plates in the window, they tell me. Drove away all done and happy that nothing major got in the way.   
In the end, costs came in close enough to my estimate, although I still don't have confirmation on the MFK test cost, done a few weeks ago. I am not sure I would go through all this again, but as I said before the car was cheap and good enough so I think it was worth it in this instance. If I had a regular day job, I definitely would not have attempted it regardless. Happy to answer any related questions.

Pity you got the wrong engine type....   
After carefull study I ordered a bike with a motor on the crank for my GF (for engine, see  )   
I'm building an electric bike at home for myself, in the course of this I did some calculations. Too get a bit more technical, it turns out that    
Power_losses / Power_delivered is proportional to 1 / engine_speed^2   
So, for a certain delivered power level the losses reduce with the engine speed squared.    
Going uphill the rear-wheel engine of your stromer runs at a low speed, losses are high. At high speed all is OK as this greatly reduces the losses (at 30 kmh the losses are only 1/9 of those when you go uphill at 10kmh, assuming same delivered power)   
With the engine at the crank however there driver will always select a gear where the crank rotates at around 60 to 80 rpm, independent of the actual road speed. This means the engine can be optimised much easier, the range of speeds it works at is small. Because of the selected gear engine speed will always be high, also for going uphill.   
This was comfirmed by the bike shop where we ordered my GF's bike. They went up the Uetliberg with similar bikes, one with the BionX wheel engine and another with the Bosch crank engine. The range of the BionX was much smaller than of the Bosch engine (even though battery capacity is very similar). Indicative of power_loss, the BionX engine got very warm while the Bosch engine stays cool. The difference in efficiency is so big that the regeneration of energy as performed by the BionX did not compensate for its low efficiency (the Bosch crank engine has no regeneration).

Regardless of the logistics, I can suggest bringing the car over. We brought our car over from London and the process was not that painful. Sure, at parking barriers you need to clamber or get one of those grabber things and if you want to sell the thing, you might as well push it in the lake, but if it's paid off and you need a car for shopping and the odd trip, hold onto it. The alternative is selling it in the UK (Assume you get 38 pence) and buy a car here. (Assume slightly more than 38 pence) Don't let people scare you, it's not that complicated. What the guy wants to do, I think, is have the car checked over and any faults identified now so he can claim for the repair on the warranty which expires soon.  I don't think he ever asked "should I extend the warranty", even if it might be a good idea.   
If there are no error codes showing up and the car is running fine, I seriously doubt any garage will find something for which the warranty will pay out on, even if they do an oil analysis.  Tearing down the engine just to have a look also wouldn't be cost effective, unless they did in fact find something, but the car would already be telling you that.   
I'd google for common problems on this model and decide what to do about warranty extension then.  Beware though, I did it for my E46 and it only made me feel sick.  I think the newer models have fewer problems.

On this website   you can look up timetables. 
Best is to choose non-rush-hour, such as Sunday morning at 10h, when not so many people are out and about. 
After you've entered the departure and destination, etc., click on "find a connection". 
Choose the option with the least number of changes. 
Now scroll down and you will see, below the timetable, the option "barrier-free travel".  If you click on that, you will be guided towards pavement-level trains, trams and buses, so that you can move easily.   
Good idea to strap the mattress up, cover it well with plastic (just in case it rains) and then bind the whole thing to a trolley, so you can just wheel it into and out of the public transport.   
If you smile at people waiting at the stop - well before the tram arrives or well before you reach your stop - and ask them for their help, you will most likely find that people will gladly assist you in your enterprise.

With a "grey import" waranties can be only 2 years as opposed to 3 years, but if the car is relatively new you can buy additional years of guarantee at reasonable prices, to give an idea, i paid 1700 for 2 extra years on a car that new costs around Chf 180k.   
It is very easy to import yourself, you can check cars/prices very easily, in English on     Main dealers are here so this lessens the risk of getting screwed over.   
At the border, you get the German VAT (19%) deducted, you pay 8% Swiss VAT + 4% Car tax, with these papers and the Certificate of Conformity you go to your vehicle test center who give you an appointment and perform a prefunctory test and issue a Swiss grey card. One thing they do check on carefully is that the wheels are correct size for the car.   
If the car is less than 6 months old, as determiend by first registration, then you pay a CO2 tax that can be quite chunky, depending on the vehicle.   
For a small car, it's probably not worth bothering unless you are prepared to buy unseen and just go up to pick it up, for a larger car, it's certainly worth it.   
It really is, exceedingly easy and uncomplicated to do yourself !

Looks to be overfilled to me. I'm not familiar with that particular engine, but I would guess more than 1l too much. It is probably black because by lifting the front you only got a portion of the old oil out.   
Measure how much oil you drained and compare that to how much fresh oil you added. This will give you an accurate enough measure of how much too much. Go to the building center and get some plastic tubing of a small enough diameter that it will fit into the dipstick tube and siphon that much off. Alternately, use the drain plug but this is a bit tricky to extract a specific amount. It would appear to be a cartridge filter, so you don't need to account for the oil contained in the old filter.   
Do NOT run the engine until you have the oil level at or slightly below the "full" marking.    
I hate to say this, but it may already be too late and you've the blown seals out of the top end - this will be more expensive to rectify than having a mechanic change your oil would have been in the first place.

As long you drive EU plated car in EU, and CH plated car in CH, you should fine and it doesn't matter who owns/drives it then (as long as by permission). Questions will be raised once you cross border into a customs region which considers you its resident - from their point of view you may be importing a foreign car.      I really wouldn't count on that. Ask a lawyer if your situation is as complicated as you describe - a simple preventive consultation will be far cheaper than a potential court case about smuggling. Well, that's one of the routes they take. Having the pleasure of doing my driving test twice, you also have the option of going on to the motorway and then exiting for Uetikon-Waldegg - beware of the Rechtsvortritt right at the beginning of the village - and then back into town via the winding old road down to Albisrieden. Not sure if the Kontrollfahrt is as strict as the actual exam but you WILL have to parallel park, possibly even on a hill. You cannot use one of those automatic parking assistance thingies either. They also tend to talk to you a lot and this includes asking questions about your knowledge of the various traffic rules.     
I agree though, practice Manesseplatz (bonus points for doing it on a Friday around 17.00), the general area around the STVA, don't forget to turn off the engine if you happen to arrive and have to stop for the train going through on Uetlibergstrasse, in the little side roads it's all about the Rechtsvortritt, don't be lazy about changing gear and using the clutch on roundabouts (a friend got failed for keeping the clutch down while going around a roundabout). I'm not sure how specific that stuff is to Switzerland, since I learned to drive here.

If you whacked a wheel enough to bend it, you may need to have the car competently realigned as well. The bent wheel may also not run straight and true, balancing won't cure that, only replacing or fixing may.    
You may have a combination of faults giving you the chase around, bushings, bearings, etc. Hopefully you have a competent Mini or BMW garage. If you are trying to save money by going to independents, if they aren't competent with Minis it might cost you more in the long run.

Filing in person is recommended, if you file by (e)mail they'll most probably have questions anyway. Expect for things to take more than just a few minutes, half to a full hour perhaps. Some stations are staffed on saturdays, perhaps that's most convenient for you, though some of these are by appointment only.    
Personally I'd talk to the company first. Not to some infodesk clerk, but to top management, ideally to the owner. Perhaps print the stuff and hand it over. If the reply is in a reasonable tone I'd leave it at that as a first step, and repeat when necessary (when, not if, as people are used to their parking style so it won't fully work on the first go). The higher the rank of the person I speak to the more I'd not mention police (or only in passing), this option is a given and always open.   
If however the people I'd talk to were getting abusive or were not open to my complaint I'd involve the police immediately.    
Talking to the company first would also allow to make sure what Teverus describes doesn't apply. I think in every case a 'real' sidewalk has demarcations both on the street side and on the side where the private area is. If however what looks like a sidewalk is actually private property there should be no demarcation separating it from the private area.

Hi, last year an impressive 40% of newly registered cars in Switzerland were 4WD, in Q1 of this year even 43%. In Graubünden even 74%. Soon 1 in 2 new cars will have 4WD. But of course, the average age of a car being about 7 years old, AWD are still not so common on Swiss roads. But still probably the highest percentage in Europe. Can you explain that?    
Of course a 2WD will do perfectly fine in most conditions, but AWD undeniably contributes to greater personal/road safety, just like wearing a helmet when biking/skiing, airbags, winter tires, having sufficient power/torque -- 
none of which is in the Swiss law.
Urs speaks English and can do his classes in that language, but be aware that he has his own program and doesn't take students looking for the minimum, so it will get expensive. Worth it though.

I've been buying tickets on my mobile for a year now,mand I can guarantee you that it will take longer to control people. Since the validity date no longer appears on the card, they will have to scan every single card like they do with the mobile tickets. It takes quite a bit of time, especially when the train ride is bumpy. The controller has to take out his phone, get the scanner on, scan your card (while not moving), put back his phone if the next ticket is a paper ticket, then take it out again for next Swisspass, and so on... Not exactly time-saving for the employees on the train.   
But they'll be saving on plastic, since you keep the same card for 5 years and can switch between 1/2 Takst and GA without changing card. Possibly even have other type of fare cards.   
For me as a user, I'm pretty happy I went from 1/2 Takst to GA a week ago, just early enough to get te old card. I don't really see what's in it for me at this point in time, I don't use Mobility or any other services where Swisspass is supposed to be useful. Trollefar got his Swisspass yesterday, he's not so happy about it.   
We don't really mind the automatic renewal though; as long as you don't need to send a hand-written letter signed with your blood by recommended mail delivered by a unicorn (like trying to cancel anything in France) I find it rather practical.

Okay, maybe no one has bought theirs from Argos, but I thought it worth posting just in case.   
High Street chain Argos is recalling five car seat models made by the nursery products brand Mamas & Papas.    
It has told parents to stop using the seats "immediately" over safety fears.   
It is feared the models may not protect children in the event of a crash, with their shells cracking under impact.   
The affected models are Mamas & Papas Mercury Group 1 Black, Mercury Group 1 Grey, Mercury Group 1-2-3 Black, Mercury Group 1, 2, 3 Grey, Mercury Group 2-3 Black and Grey.   
Mamas & Papas said no incident had been reported to it related to any of the recalled car seats, which it makes solely for Argos.   
In a statement Mamas & Papas added: "We continue to work closely with Argos to determine the exact nature of the issue.   
"All Mamas & Papas car seats are tested, certified and approved under the European regulations R44/04 by independent accredited bodies."       
Argos said in a statement: "We have identified a potential safety concern.   
"In the event of an accident the car seat shell may crack and therefore not provide the intended level of protection to the user."   
It said that any customers who had bought one of the seats "should immediately stop using the product" and return it to an Argos store for a full refund.   
"We wish to thank you for your co-operation and apologise for any inconvenience caused by this recall."   
The Argos catalogue numbers of the affected car seat models are 297/7526, 411/9100, 305/6037, 397/9530, and 245/4829.   
Jim Holder is the editorial director at Haymarket Automotive, which publishes WhatCar and AutoCar magazines.   
He said that child seats were like crash helmets, in that "once it's damaged... the integrity of that seat is pretty much finished, so any slight damage is to be avoided".

Hi all,  
Sorry to dig up an old thread but I wanted to add some valuable info for the community.   
Yesterday I got a notification of a speeding fine for being 6kph over the 50kph limit (after they removed the 5kph for margin of error it was only 51kph but the Swiss like their rules!).  The bill was 40CHF from the Police in Neuchatel. 
I was immediately suspicious as I have never heard of the place I was supposed to have been caught in as well as it being in a different canton some miles away from me.  I looked it up on Google maps and indeed it was a mystery.  I checked my location history on Google Maps too (amazing service, use it people!).  I was safely tucked up in bed at 05:47 that morning...   
So I did some research on EF and found this thread as well as a couple more giving valuable info. 
I took the advice and called the Police this morning.  A very friendly lady took the matter seriously and said she would go and check the photo with her superior.  She called me back 30 minutes later and confirmed that it was indeed an error because the numberplate was not clearly visible on the car in question.  As such, she cancelled the fine and apologized for the inconvenience.  She is sending me a confirmation letter stating that the fine is no longer valid (by B post, how quaint).     
So people, if you get a ticket and you are sure it was not you, don't despair.  These systems are not infallible and the Police do seem to be reasonable about it, in canton NE at least.  Do your research, check where you were (use Google Location History if you use an Android phone), call the people up and be humble.  I didn't go in all guns blazing and it seemed to work very well indeed.   
I was convinced last night that I was being stitched up but I am so relieved today that my name stays off 'the list'.  You all know about that list that the Swiss keep of all naughty foreigners, right....?

I hate people on the phone who decide to risk my safety when driving, assholes!   
Careful with this though I checked and hands free is not the same as integrated systems which are part of the car. If the system is supplied or fitted into the car it is allowed in France. *Which makes Zero sense?!!*   
It's the morons with the iphone headsets plugged in oblivious to all around them they're after. Still either way your call seems more important than my safety.

Hi all,   
This is not so much an advertisement of a driving school as something rather useful for anyone who wants to get their A1 (roller/scooter) or A license (motorcycle).     
If anyone wants to get one of those licenses, you will need to get a permit and then take either 8 or 12 hours of a Grundkurs in 4 months so that the full A1 is granted or the A permit is extended for 12 months.   
I decided to get my A license, and imagine my surprise when I found out that I would need to rent my own motorcycle.....  You do not want to know the terms of the rental - the price is not too bad, but if you damage the bike - you are out 1500 CHF regardless of whether it was your fault or not.  You also have a problem with the fact that you have to get that rental motorcycle through the city to the driving school for your course. 
I can guarantee that this would be "a lot of fun" if you've never been on a motorcycle before.   
And there were no motorcycle schools out there, which have their own motorcycles or scooters to rent - I could not find any in Basel.   
Well, now there is one: Fahrschule Sunna.   
The school has scooters, motorcycles and gear (helmets, jackets, boots, gloves) for rent - the prices are better than at the motorcycle rental places and if you drop the bike you will not be charged if it happens while taking the course.   
The owner (Oktay) is a pretty good instructor and speaks great English. 
I finished my Grundkurs with him without any incidents      
The season has started!   If anyone wanted to learn how to ride or to figure out if you would like it but this whole "have to have your own scooter/motorcycle and gear bit" was stopping you, it no longer has to    
Cheers

As soon as you paid the car you are the owner. No further paperwork needed. 
To drive the car you would need a license plate. To get the license plate you need a vehicle liability insurance coverage first, then you have to register a holder at the StVA. (The holder is liable for tax, road worthiness, insurance details, and minor traffic tickets).    
Best ask the relevant authority if you could register yourself as a holder:

Considering you stay less then 90 days in Switzerland, I doubt you could register yourself as a holder. And if you could, getting an insurance may be a challenge.

It's about some things that are affecting performance, emissions, handling, etc.   
For example putting spacers at the wheels needs a DTC paper (or whatever) if the track width changes more than 2%. 
Or putting exhausts, having drilled discs when the OEM ones are not drilled, etc.   
With the braided brake hoses the argument is that the ABS behaves differently, and that's why they need some kind of certification.   
They even say that they "police" re-flashing of the engine ECU but how they can do it when a well hidden parallel, or a reflash, cannot even be detected at dealerships is beyond me.   
In any case, if you want to make sure you won't have any problems don't go crazy Samco-blue fancy, and you'll be fine. They won't even notice.   
They also don't care if it's not strictly OEM sourced as long as it is OEM spec. So you don't need to get brake pads from the dealer, you can even run crazy race spec pads, but then they'll probably bust your balls about them screeching like crazy

The beginning and end of a blue zone is marked on the street itself with a blue/white bar across the street. If the white part is closer to you before you cross you're about to enter a blue zone.    
You're allowed to park in a blue zone for an unlimited time if you buy a  special sticker, but these are reserved for residents only. For mere mortals it's 60-89 minutes: Say you arrive between 09:00 and 09:29, you set the blue disk to 09:30 and are allowed to stay until 10:30. See these  . For general info on parking and additional regulations  .   
Other than that you need to check which paragraph you acted against. As has been said, that's noted on the fine slip.   
For completeness' sake (I think this is quite unlikely to apply, but still):  
The disc itself must follow certain  regulations, which changed about ten years ago. This also shold be noted on the fine slip; in such a case get one from your car insurer or buy a replacement at a gas station shop of your choice.

In Zh the online service for buying a resident's permit is looking in the ZH STVA and sees the address the car is registered at.   
If you are using a car that is not yours long term, you can go with the car's papers and something that says that the car has been loaned to you (like a letter from your friend) and go to the actual office that is administering the permits (which for ZH is near the library, keep forgetting the address). That's what I was told from that office I should do with my Greek car but I needed to translate the car papers and it was just easier (although much more expensive) to get a spot in my building garage for some months.   
Try visiting the respective office and Basel (or call them) and see what they have to say. In ZH there are also provisions for replacement cars from a garage while yours is in for repairs, and can also be given for extended periods of time with help from the garage. So I guess a permit could be given, but not for a very long time.

Mofa is short for  tor hrrad, motorized bicycle.    
The traditional meaning is a bicycle-like one-seated vehicle with pedals and a combustion engine of 50cm3 capacity with a 30km/h speed limit. A permit category M is required for these (minimum age 14 years).   
However, things have changed over the last 10-20 years, partially due to the increased useability of electric motors. There are multiple additional categories these days, including scooters (up to 50cm3 but higher speed limit, driver license category A1u).   
If you opt for an electric motor   gives a good overview, including required permits.
Use Brühltor. It has a direct access to the Tonhalle.

A fine may be issued aside from the Strafbefehl, perhaps this depends on whether you take it to court or not. If you want a reliable answer ask the authorities that sent you the Strafbefehl.   
Withdrawal of driving license for a limited period may follow. You seem to have been more than "a few" km too fast (probably more than 15km/h above the limit), otherwise there wouldn't be a Strafbefehl but just an ordinary fine.   
=====================================   
As for translation of Strafbefehl: There's none AFAIK.    
Strafbefehl is kind of a shortened trial where the prosecuting attorney issues the verdict, i.e. no judge gets involved. This only happens in minor cases where the verdict would be quite clear if actually taken to court. The idea is to take work load off the courts.   
Edit:    That will happen after the Strafbefehl has become "rechtskräftig" (legally valid).

As both your children are 4 years and over they can use a booster seat. They are reasonably price and do not take up too much space.   
Trying to use one car seat is a great idea!    
I would never just go without a carseat to pick up someone elses child or a short trip. Statics show that you are more likely to have an accident when on a short trip or within five miles of your home after a long trip! I had the most horrific car accident four years ago (not in CH) when my children were 13 months old and 6 years respectively and I was only collecting them from school, wasn't rushing around and I am convinced they survived the crash due to being in the correct car seats! My daughter is now 10 years old and still using a car seat. Accidents happen when you least expect them.   
I hope this helps - good luck!

In the latest TCS magazine (December 2015) they have an article about potential "problems" with the Mobility Car insurance program.   
The standard deductible in case of an accident (or any damage to the car) is   (or more for young and new drivers). So in the case of an accident (if you are even partially at fault), you will be on the hook for the first CHF 2'500. Also if you take the car without noticing some previous damage (that you can not prove was there), you are liable for the first CHF 2'500 of damage.       You have to ask for this option as it is not offered directly. If you rent only from time to time, you can pay CHF 20 per rental.   
Both of these premiums are per person so if you are two people in the family who rent you both have to pay.   
The TCS also recommends that you take photos of the car (any visible damage outside/inside) before you drive off so you have proof that it was there from the previous driver. You should also take photos when you return the car.    
Also as a bit of a plug for their insurance program, they also recommend you have a Livret ETI if you drive outside of CH with a Mobility car.

Update on my old thread for whoever might need the info..   
I have a class C  CDL from the US. To get my swiss CDL I had to:   
- fill out form from STVA and wait for response 
- send in my US license with one of the forms that they sent 
- get a medical exam and give the other form they sent to the doctor to sign     and mail 
- wait for another response, with a scheduled time for the written exam (not available in English)  
- take the written exam. multiple choice on a computer, given at the STVA.  
- provide proof that you have had your auslander CDL for more than 2 years, if not evident on the actual license/card   
They sent it out quickly, I go it a few days later after all said and done, along with my US license. I had taken the Kat. C test. They gave me on my Swiss license Kat. B, C, D1, BE, CE, and D1E.   
Total cost CHF 140-150, plus 120 for the med. check. Process took about a month.   
Study materials for written exam available online    
Note that for goods transport and people transport of over 8 people you now need a fähigkeitsausweis/ qualification card which requires a five day course, a written test, a spoken test, and a road test - all at a cost of many thousand CHF. You may be exempt from the tests if you were issued your CDL before 9.2008, but still need to take the course every 5 years.   
It didn't matter that I'd waited a while after arriving to transfer it, though it was no longer valid in CH (but still was in the US).    
This was in Luzern.   YMMV.   
Hope that helps someone...

I suggest you have a look at this summary of the key theory and if anything is unfamiliar you should probably swot up.     
Also remember on the motorway it's double shoulder check before changing lane and on slip roads.  It's not unusual to do a stretch on the motorway between Baden/wettingen and spreitenbach.     
Don't bother downloading maps but get out on your bike as much as possible around the test center.  Your instructor should be giving you tips on test routes, needless to say up towards boppelsen is one, back roads between wettingen and otelfingen, oetwil an der limmat etc   
Be clear on your priority from the right and show bremsbereitschaft (readiness to brake by covering the brake) as you approach priority from the right situations.   
Looks like you have the order on turning correct but don't forget einspuren (positioning in anticipation of turn) as well.  The examiners are hot on this.   
If in doubt try and squeeze in another lesson.  You'll be glad of it. 
Best of luck

As it's said above the thing you really need is the certificate of conformity.  I got sent mine for free.  I believe modifications need to be notified and you need *Swiss* approval for them, but there might be some general exceptions. This applies to wheels too. My car's on slightly lowered Eibach springs which are dark grey in colour and the MFK didn't say a thing because it still looks more or less stock.   Doesn't sound like that would be your case though. I also modified the lights to LHD and "activated" the rear fog lamp on the other side.   
For the Japanese car, you might be able to get away with a cert of partial conformity and then make the relevant mods to meet the european spec, using genuine european parts, but this being Switzerland you probably can't and/or it will be stupid expensive.   
Not that it's legal but quite a few folk drive around with UK plates for years (here in Basel where there are always French and German cars around) without ever having any problems.  Similarly they retain their UK licences but I think in most cases these people still have a home in the UK and hope to argue that they're "on holiday" or something should anything happen.  The police have basically admitted that it's not something they actively check.

It generally helps if you post the whole story when requesting help - that way you'll get a decent answer. Is this a "known" problem - IE one that you (or the vehicle owner or the son) has been aware of prior to failure? What exactly has failed? What is the 1000chf quote based on?   
A "cheap" garage is still going to charge >100chf per hour, which may sound expensive in GBP, but that low price hasn't changed from 20 years ago, a time when a local mecahnic was charging £45 per hour.    
If the car doesn't drive the mechanic my be quoting on collecting the car and towing it down to the garage and then fixing the problem.   
The question that may effect people most on here though is whether it is a CH registered car - if not, and it is being used for extended periods in Switzerland I would question whether the insurance is valid.

Technically, you can only have what's listed in the registration certificate and/or certificate of conformity, and that might well say you can have whatever you want but it might also limit your choices (which it probably won't).  I say that because my CoC is very restrictive, even limiting the brand of tyres.  As far as OEM wheels go, I'm only allowed to have one of the two different types of wheels that were available when the car was new.     
Generally speaking though, you only have to worry about the set of wheels your car will be on when you go through the MFK.

AFAIK any OEM wheels that are listed on the COC as being suitable for the vehicle do not need an additional certificate (the COC will give the sizes, not the wheel model). My steel wheel are the one listed so I suppose i do not need a certication then, pls correct me if I am wrong.

Wear and tear on engine is function not just of kilometres driven, but also number of starts (more wear is done in first second after cold starting when minimal oil lubricates the engine than in several minutes of warm highway driving) and frequency of maintenance.  Also, things like window switches, rubber seals around car, lamps, cloth or leather seats, etc are function of time and weather exposure than kilometres driven. 
So, a garaged 4 year old car with 200k Km but with documented regular service record and driven mostly on smooth highway for extended periods would be my strong choice over a 8 year old car with 100k, with no service record, used only on short in-town jaunts by a guy who lives on a rutted road with lots of potholes. 
Good luck on your decision!

I've done trips between various places in the Netherlands and Pays de Gex or Valais many times now, both via France and via Germany and there are advantages and disadvantages to both routes.   
France has a nice long area of relatively cheap peage (around 20 EUR), which is a nice road to drive on as it's rather quiet (between Dole and Nancy), just set the cruise control to 130 and go. The pass through the Jura mountains near the Pays de Gex is quite beautiful, but might not be nice to drive in the winter with snow. Luxembourg has cheap gas. But the roads outside the peage and the Belgian highway aren't that great.   
The German route has the advantage of large swaths of highway with no speed limit. Going up to 160+ can save you quite some time, if you drive outside rush hours. The roadside facilities are a bit nicer in Germany than in France. But there are a lot of "baustellen" (construction works) that cause slowdowns or traffic jams. And the highways around large cities can be very crowded in rush hour.   
For us, the decission is now primarily made based upon our destination in NL (or departure point). The more west that is, the more likely we are to choose the French route.

They very deliberately teach the children to wait until the car is fully stopped before crossing,

In Australia, you must stop no further back than something like 1 metre, but not over the crossing paint, and you must come to a complete stop...crawling to avoid having to completely stop the vehicle is not OK.    
Anyway, makes sense to me, but having observed many many children trying to cross the road using the 'policeman's rules'....there are a large percentage of drivers who either fail to stop, slow down but do not come to a full stop, or stop miles back from the crossing....both driver and child become quite confused.   
If you have not come to a full stop and applied your brakes, you are not in control of your vehicle, so please come to a full stop so the little kids can cross safely...thank you!!

There is a new CO2 tax for cars less than 6 months old (where "old" means the date from the first registration).  Its huge.  On my M4 sportscar, its something like 24k CHF if I did it myself, or 7k CHF if I went through a dealer.   
I will also have to pay customs and VAT, because I have not owned the car for 6 months.  This ends up being roughly 12 percent of the value of the car.   
Shipping costs were something around 5k but this includes marine insurance for the full value of the car in USD.   
Conversion costs for the car, just to bring it up to "legal" standards in Switzerland were quoted at roughly 7k CHF by two garages (autociel and autolassung).   
So bringing this car over is roughly a 30k CHF proposition with CO2 tax, or a 23(ish)k CHF proposition without it.   
Either way, believe it or not, its still cheaper than buying the car new, in Switzerland... but not by much.   
Ultimately I have decided to ship the car a bit later and avoid the CO2 tax.     
I'll let you know how it goes.

A late thanks for all the replies - after many months it is finally done so I would like to post an update in case it helps anyone else. Here are the steps I went through to temporarily import the car for 2 years.   
1. One problem was that when we entered and registered with the Zoll we were not given a 13.20 form with Stammnummer. This I had to corect by going to Strassenverkehrsamt and they gave me an empty form and a new Stammnummer.   
2. Finding an insurance that will insure a foreign plates car temporarily - This was a difficult step. In the end "Zurich Connect" referred us to "Zurich" which does this and we had to meet up in person to do this.   
3. With the insurance I went back to SVA and we were able to get an appointment for MFK.   
4. After 1.5 months we went through the MFK, after passing it (on 2nd appointment because some things had to be done) we were given the new license plate (ZHxxxxZ as a temporary plate) and Swiss registration document on the spot and gave our old license plate back to SVA to send to NL.   
5. We had to send back to NL ourselves our old registration documents for them to unregister the car in NL so we don't have to pay road taxes there and cancelled NL insurance.    
Tricky but not impossible

I had it from the horse's mouth that it's basically all down to money and politics. If it were down to the Schiffahrtskontrolle, they'd recognise licences perfectly willingly, they know exactly what a Yachtmaster ticket entails - and it's a far higher level than the Hochseeschein. But the powers-that-be dictate these things. I gather the reason for the tightening up of mutual recognition was down to that weasel word "mutual". The Swiss decided they weren't going to recognise tickets from nations that didn't recognise their tickets in return.   
FWIW whilst the regulations regarding the storm lights haven't changed (slow = start making your way home, fast = get off the water now, do not pass go, do not collect £200), the criteria for their use changed last year. Under the old system they used to be switched on when a storm was expected within the next 2-3 hours (or thereabouts) (slow) or within the next hour-ish (fast). As of spring 2014 that has now changed to a more logical slow = winds of 25-33 kt expected, fast = winds of over 33 kt expected. It seems to have led to a much more accurate reflection of what's going to happen, making the system more reliable. Interestingly, although only two speeds of flash are advertised (slow = 40/min, fast = 90/min), going my observations there is in fact a third speed that seems to be at 120/min. Whenever I've seen that, it's usually really meant it.

The drivers are not penalized for a card payment - they are paying the credit card companies a fee for using a service offered by them. Nobody is forced to accept credit cards... it is a choice.   
I am not sure how you thought credit cards work but simply put: Every shop or cafe pays Amex/Visa/Mastercard for every single transaction. Usually in the lower one digit percentage between 3-5% of the total.    
Amex is notorious for being the most expensive one. I am an avid user of their card as it gives me the best benefits... at the costs of the merchants. Merchants are not allowed to charge extra for the CC usage, otherwise it would be nice and transparent. So here you go: a company that accepts credit cards of course calculates the average fees when they come up with their prices. If anyone in this system is penalized is it not the taxi drivers, but the people who pay cash and unknowingly cover for the fees of the credit card users...

Most car speedometers read about 5% high - a deliberate setting from the manufacturer. Different tyre & wheel combinations can change the true speed from the reported speed so they build in some leeway. The police then apply a margin of error on the reading they take - usually 2 to 3km per hour upto 100 kph and then 3% above that (It's a few months since my last bill so I don't remember exactly). If you were doing an indicated 70 then your real speed would have been about 66 to 67 and they'd then knock 2 or 3 kph off for their margin for error - so you should just get lucky and scrape in at about 15 kph over the limit.   
Good luck.

Yes, like two days when you have Form 15.25. Or you may get Form 15.30 which gives you a longer time if you meet certain conditions.   
Both forms must be acquired at the very first border crossing, otherwise you will do a tax and/or duty violation.  If caught you will be liable for any tax and duty due PLUS up to 5 times the tax and duty as penalty.    
Art. 118 Swiss Customs Law.     
Considering tax for a car is 4% + 8% = 12.32%, you may have to pay up to a total of 73.92% of the cars value (and more if duty is due)   
Edit: Additionally up to one year in jail or a fine up to CHF 30'000

Commonly known as "sh!t in the carbs". Can sometimes be sorted just by spraying   in through the air inlet (having disconnected filter).      Yes, plugs should be cleaned too, but while replacing the fuel won't do any harm and may help flush out any residue in the tank or fuel filter, the fuel itself should be fine. The idea that it can "go off" is a myth, albeit one frequently believed and repeated.    
Largely it's based on the idea that some of the petrol components are more volatile than others and will evaporate sooner, leaving a less easily combustible mixture, but in fact the volatility variance is very little, so it would take years in an unsealed container for the mixture to change significantly. What can and does happen is that evaporation will cause deposits to build up in the fuel lines, carbs, etc. so flushing the who;e system out often makes it appear like the fuel was itself the problem.

If you want to sell a car privately and do so quickly - go to autoscout, search for similar cars, price yours 500chf lower and wait for the phone to ring.   
Whatever you do don't overprice it from the start - be realistic - accept that every CHF above 5,000 is a win - and taking 6,000chf after 1 week is likely to be better than taking 6,000chf after 3 months.

Nope, they have the same number but are completely separate - the number is just to identify you as a person when you buy a personal (non-transferable) pass. In fact, there's no discount in the monthly/yearly passes for having a Halb-tax.   
Sharing the number just means that if you get a new card you don't need to give them your details and picture all over again - they already have them. I had a yearly pass long before I got a halb-tax, and when I bought a halb-tax they just took the number to get the picture and personal details.

Riehen has become a blue-zone-only area.    
You can however buy a visitor's parking ticket for chf 6 for half a day or chf 10 for a full day. It's valid for blue zones all over Basel and is available online and at public transport ticket machines.

A lot of times they're positioned higher up on a pass watching the activity below. More than a few of our EF bikers group have gotten tickets around there, apparently, though not I - I've yet (knock on wood) to get busted on the bike, though I have a lot of 1kph tickets in my car built up!

Hello Ladies and Gentelmen,   
I'm learningn to drive and I thought it could be helpful to give a bit of info about the process.   
-First I did the Nothelfer Kurs, in english in sanarena, you only have to assist the two days and they will give to you the certificate. 
-Then the eye test (I just search the closest place near my home and asked if it was valid for the driving license) 
-Then I bought the fuhrerschein cd and studied the content for about 3 months (no rush) when I saw that I was doing 97% questions correct I did the test (in english). 
	You can choose the language of the test when you start the test, but the reservation process for the date and the papers are the same if you are doing it in english german or another language. 
-Less than a week later I received my temporary student driving license and started practising.   
The first hours I practised at a company's parking lot (I don't know if it's allowed because I dont work for that company but I went always after 7p.m. an it was almost always empty) The coordinates of the parking lot are: 47.339889, 8.517879 (you can just search them in google maps) 
When I could break, use the gear and felt a bit more confident I went to a place near my work (47.359188, 7.970602) there you have long roads without interceptions To be more specific Industriestrasse -> Güterstrasse -> Aarefelstrasse (you can do a circle with this tree streets) 
Now I'm practising again in zurich in Birmensdorf (not a lot of traffic) 
Oh and by the way, I'm practising with my husband, when he considers I'm driving perfectly, I'll do the verkehrskundekurs and then a couple of hours with a professional just to be sure and then the test.       
Lets see how it goes (sorry for the bad english)

It depends which boat you catch. Some of them go direct, others make a few stops but all on the Thalwil side of the lake so your ticket is still OK, and others zigzag back and forth to the Küsnacht side which would mean you'd need an extra ticket for that zone.   
Best way to find out is to check the  . Enter Zürich Bürkliplatz and Thalwil ZSG, then go to "advanced search" and select only boats as your means of travel... this weeds out all those pesky tram-and-rail options.   
Now, for whichever boat you're considering, click "Show intermediate stops". Your ticket needs to cover all the zones where those stops are located.       
FWIW Zürich is actually the   end of the lake (the Limmat flows out, not in). The term "upper lake" or "Obersee" does exist, but it refers to the bit at the other end, past Rapperswil and Pfäffikon.

You will struggle to find a good car there - and if you do you'll have to do all the paperwork/running around/registration/MFK yourself. Unless you are absolutely sure you are getting a bargain - I would steer clear.   
I see the Swiss market as:      - popular - bought on lease from main dealers. Big Swiss companies will have a fleet policy that private individuals can use to get a discount.     - typically 4 years old and younger. Ex-lease. Part exchanged for another car at the dealership. Usually found at main dealers.      - pile em high - sell em cheap places. (Auto Discount Uster) - good deals of new or newish cars - average specification - bugger all service - and you are best advised going with cash.      - traditional car dealer. Cars around 4-10 years old. Some very good - some tired. Good examples near Zurich are F+G and Gfenn - both in Dubendorf. Service can be good or poor depending on who you speak to. Cars should come with a fresh MFK.      - more often used for exporting cars - with odd bargain. Avoid unless you absolutely know what you are looking for     - A lot of mechanics will also sell a few cars. They are often in very good mechanical condition (because the mechanic has done the work). If not they'll advise on the costs.    
And finally notes on what to buy. 
High mileage immaculate condition cars aren't liked in Switzerland. If you buy one, no matter how good it is, you'll struggle to sell for a good price. I got stung on this when my wife insisted I sell a car - I didn't want to - but she thought she knew best - as it transpired - she didn't.   
Cars in colour combinations you might like - the market won't like!

Hello Anushka,      Normally this would cost around 2500 - 3000 CHF in Lausanne with all charges (medical courses, books, learning with instructor, etc). I went through this with my wife recently and most of the driving instructors in Lausanne charge you around 100 CHF per academical hour (50 min). They would recomend around 20 to 40 hours of practicing.   
Of course, you can try to do this with your boyfriend of husband, but the practical exams are quite strict in canton VD and I doubt that driving with non professional instructor will make you pass. It will be helpful for sure, but the devil is in details, so ... Some people seem to pass just with 6 - 8 hours of practicing, however as they say "hope for the best, plan for the worst". You need to plan the worst case scenario. That means that once you started the process you will wish to finish it since this is costly. In that sense it is better to plan ahead and make sure you will have enough money to continue learning.

post:
I brought the issue up not by way of complaint but because it caught a few people by surprise and being forewarned is good. Only some European countries require renewal (and/or testing) of senior drivers.    
This is not the only anomaly that has caught me out: I had a UK-reg car in Switzerland stored in my closed garage. There is an EU law that states a car not taxed (or equivalent) in its home EU Member State can not be driven in any other. It could be driven (under specific conditions, including non-residence) in Switzerland but not in France. It could be driven from Dover to London (or anywhere in the UK) if there was a pre-scheduled MOT. How to get it to Dover other than (1) towing, (2) freight on the back of a lorry, (3) dealer plates (not possible in the UK as transport plates can only be placed on a car owned by the dealer: this makes little sense to me but it's what DLVA told me, perhaps incorrectly; BBC Radio 4 had a programme on transporters ("trade plate" drivers):   ).    
(In the end we junked the car. Possible in Switzerland (we gave it to a dealer), but not in France: I wrecked a UK car once (tire blowout) and it had to be towed back to the UK for junking. So my insurer said; and surprisingly they were nice to me when they discovered it was diplomatic and not taxed or duty-paid anywhere. But that was years ago.)     
Returning to the over-70s medical: I linked to the Génération article (on line for 15 days from the posting) because it has new information. And BTW the medical can be taken 2 months before, or with permission 1 month after, the 70th birthday. So what if one is on a long holiday in Canada? (Fortunately I have a Québec licence too. But not everybody does.)   
Again: this is not a complaint. As forum posts are searchable forever on Google and other search engines, it's intended for anyone who cares to know. Usually I link to legal references but European Law (search for "Driving Licence Directive" and "Directives and regulations - motor vehicles") and Swiss law on vehicles and licensing are easy enough to find.   
The fact is that people get away with a lot of stuff. The Swiss cantons will send a letter to the last known address of driver licence holders approaching age 70. There is a penalty for failure to submit to a medical test or turn in one's licence. In the EU a person living in another Member State is not obliged to exchange his or her licence, or even notify of a change in address to another country, until age 70. At that point the UK (and perhaps other countries) require a foreign EU licence to be exchanged and the driver's health self-certified. No penalty for not -- unless you get caught driving. And with the abolition of tax discs and CCTVs (including portables) everywhere, and the collating of vehicle and driver information (Chris Huhne, pay attention) there is a high risk of getting caught, eventually.   
A significant percentage of drivers whose licences are suspended or cancelled drive anyway. More's the pity: in some countries (USA) that invalidates their insurance. In other countries the insurer (or the country's Motor Insurance Bureau) has to pay, but can in principle sue their policyholder. (Indeed the Bureau has to pay even if the registration number plates are fake or stolen, so long as they are from another Green Card country. (Good luck collecting from some countries, but that's another story.))   
Who knows this stuff? Who cares?   
And, hey, who are "normal" people? Especially on this forum, given it's intended for those with a foreign connection.

For under 5,000chf you can either get very lucky - or badly burned. Finding a fresk service/mfk vehicle is key - and then stick to the known high-KM cars. These are the ones that can be resold in Switzerland.   
Generally the order for that is: Merc, Audi, Volvo, VW, Saab, BMW. I was told at the weekend they'd rather try to sell a 250k Saab than a 175k BMW    
None of that takes into account age - but the same is true, stick to the solid/premium makes and things tend to run well. This means components are well made. Stuff can, and certainly will go wrong, but less frequently than on older makes - and a 15 year old car from one of the above is still a good piece of kit that will happily cross a continent.   
Saying all that: 
1) Avoid the Merc A-class it is woeful. 
2) The old Merc 2.9 diesel found better use in the Sprinter. It is neither powerfull nor fuel efficient 
3) 11l/100km is what a petrol Merc will drink (assuming mixed driving) - whether it is 4 or 6 cylinder!! 
4) Do not buy a FWD Audi with the Multitronic gearbox. 
5) High KM Audis litter the Export dealers - make sure when they say "with MFK" they mean freash one!! 
6) Audi A2 is a bargain used - around 4-7k will get you the 1.4TDi or 1.6FSI model. A lot are well specced inside 
7) The S60/V70/S80 D5 (163ps pre-particulate filter) is the one to have 
8) VW 1.9 TDI  engines are gruff and noisey - but arguably the most fuel efficient engine of the era 
9) The 2.3 engine in the 9-5 is the pick of the bunch - Saab engineered through and through and no thirstier than the 2.0. The 3.0TiD has known oil level, cylinder liner and EGR issues. 
10) The BMW M20 engines sound very nice (late 80s) but are moving into collectors status.  
11) The M52B28 in 3er and 5er is one of BMWs absolutely best engines - expect around 9.5l/100km for mostly motorway driving. 
12) The 3.0d is very reliable and infinitely smoother than the 25tds engine that came before it.

So here is my wife and my experiences in converting our US licenses (state of Missouri) to Swiss licenses in Zurich Kanton.   
Completed the eye exams at our local optician (optiker) office.  Cost was 15-20 sfr.  My exam was actually completed in Zug Kanton so the Kanton doesn't matter.  The tests took 10-15 minutes and were a basic read the chart and peripheral vison tests.     
We then visit the strassenvehrkehrsamt with the following item: 
-completed application (with eye test information) 
-resident permit ID card  
-existing US drivers license 
-ID photo from one of the photo booths   
It turns out my wife and my situations were different as we both had Missouri licenses but issued at different times as we were married in 2013 and she changed her name requiring a new license    
- my missouri license had no issue date, only an expiration date (2017).  Initially this was going to be a problem and would have required a letter from the state of Missouri showing the issue date.  Fortunately the lady helping us asked her supervisor who found a letter from another Missouri driver in the past stating the issue date was six years before the expiration.  With the letter they had my documents were complete.     
-my wife's Missouri license was a new version and actually had an issue and expiration date.  Unfortunately the issue date was July 2013 (name change in June due to marriage).  Her date of entry to switzerland was in June 2014.  When they processed her license application it provided her a learners license which requires 2 driving classes (about 900 sfr) in the next year.  However, the lady helping us instructed that if my wife can show evidence of a license for just one additional month she will be issued a full license without the learners requirement.  Thankfully my wife did have a license longer so once we receive proof of this using picture of old license or letter from state we can email it to the strassenvehrkehrsamt amt referencing her PIN number and her license will be updated.   
We will both receive our licenses in the post in about a week.  I'm sure they will be accompanied with the invoice as well.

If you're leaving home at 5-6am and not getting back until 6-7pm you're not going to have much time with the family.  And anyway his family isn't in Geneva, they're based in France so an even longer journey time.      Wrong.  It matters very much what type of permit you have.    As said, if he's non-EU and has a G permit, meaning he must return to his home in France at least once a week, then he cannot transfer that permit to Zurich because Zurich is not in a border zone.  Nor for that matter could he move it to Basel because he doesn't live in a zone that borders it.  However, if he's EU then he can still keep his G permit and work in Zurich because he's allowed to work anywhere in Switzerland and is not restricted by the various border zone treaties.       
If he has a non-EU B permit which is tied to his employer he's supposed to live in the same canton as his workplace, but it is possible to live in another canton  .  Only if you're a non-EU and have an "open" B permit which isn't tied to an employer can you live where you want.  Or if you're married to a Swiss/EU national and have either a B or C permit of course.

In CH number plates are considered an attribute (so to say) of the  owner, as opposed to some other countries where they're considered  attribute of the car. Thus no need for new plates when changing the car.   
Your initial point b), namely selling the car allows you to cancel your existing insurance, is correct. But you need another insurance (Versicherungsnachweis, proof of insurance) before you're allowed to drive the new car with your number plates.   
Proof of insurance simply means the acknowledgement by the insurance that they're willing to insure the new car. If you want to cancel you most probably need to do that before bringing your new car into circulation, and the sooner the better. If you can do a few days without a car it's probably best to wait for acknowledgment of cancellation before signing the new contract.   
The new insurance company wants to bind you as long as possible, there's no need for you to accept that - demand shorter minimal duration and threaten to walk away if they refuse. Presumably the sales agent is paid by premium volume generated so he  personally has an interest in those 5 years minimum duration. OTOH you can always transfer car ownership to whomever you like and cancel your then-current insurance, doesn't matter if those 5 years have passed or not.   
One more thing:  
Your old insurance may make you a better offer if you talk to them  
Maybe the new insurance simply gives you a better rebate. And of course, less expensive doesn't mean better (except, I think, for 3rd party liability which may be the same for every company).

Because economists compare a standardised product basket which makes very little sense - this produce basket might not include taxi rides but does typically include a 100 sqm three bedroom one family house and a mid sized car - two things which are a luxury in Singapore. I am currently thinking of buying a Mazda 3 and they cost around 80k CHF new (!).   
Most of those economists happen to be American or European and therefore define a product basket based on what a typical European lives like and buys in a supermarket. In other parts of the world are many of these products rather exotic and therefore expensive... or to make the story short: if you live an European life is Singapore as expensive as Zurich. If you live a more local life is it WAY cheaper. A package of imported cheese or yoghurt in an expat-oriented super market is more expensive than a decent local dinner. Swiss people on the other hand put owning a car over using taxi services... so act the same or get switzerlanded for your in Swiss eyes luxurious demands.    
Bottom line: When in Rome...

I imported two cars from France this year. No issues at all if the car is in good technical condition. But be ware, the Swiss inspection can be tough on even small dents in the body-work, e.g. a cracked plastic bumper would not pass here (that's usually no problem in France).    
We also came from Paris and there you can\t abvoid people denting your car, so if there are loads of cosmetic/mechanical issues you will probably have to add to the cost to get those fixed in time for the inspection. And if you need to fix it, do so in France. It is  a lot cheaper than here (really, a lot).   
I would also only import the car if it has use value to you, as older cars (especially with high mileage) are next to worthless on the Swiss used car market, so you might get a bit more for your car in France if you sell it. The choice really depends on what you would buy instead (and where).

No. It's not.      Only if you were driving dangerously.   
The way you answered the question, and indeed the question itself, is making a huge level of assumption. Only if you have an accident that was clearly your fault and clearly related to your driving too fast (or whatever) for winter conditions, which might have been OK if you had winter tyres fitted, would any such action be considered.   
So you're perfectly fine to drive all year on summer tyres, and at no risk of prosecution or insurance problems, as long as you drive appropriately for the conditions. Which might mean, for example, driving much more slowly, avoiding certain roads at certain times, using chains if there's snow on the roads, or whatever else may be considered normal and sensible.    
Lack of winter tyres may be a factor to be considered in the event of an accident investigation, but no more than anything else. Having bald tyres, faulty brakes, no windscreen washer fluid or broken light bulbs may also have just as much an effect on the outcome, as would being too tired, having drunk too much, driving without prescribed spectacles or under the influence of medication. All of these, and much more, could be taken into consideration in just the same way.

I think the debate between the "start on a 50cc rat bike" and "start on a cheap 600-800cc bike that you'll actually like" will not end. I found the most important characteristics of a beginners bike are:   
 - Low center of gravity 
 - Low weight 
 - Smooth and forgiving throttle 
 - Upright seating position   
Low center of gravity and low weight will make the bike feel more agile and easier to turn. A smooth throttle is important because the last thing you want is a jerky throttle that delivers power too fast or in an uneven fashion. Finally, an upright seating position will make you feel more secure on your first rides. When you are still putting your feet down all the time, the last thing you want is a body position that effectively forces you to lie down face forward like on sport bikes.   
I don't subscribe to the notion that you must buy a weak engined bike because you are a muppet and won't resist the temptation of going full throttle on your second ride. If you are a responsible adult and will use the throttle responsibly, it does not matter that the top speed of the bike is 200+. You'll simply stay out of that range until you have your license and are ready to take it to a circuit or the autobahn. Besides, I don't find going fast in a straight line exciting at all. Much better to do some twisties (of which we have no shortage in CH) and for most of them you will be in the 30-80 range for a while.

I bought a Disco (2008) model - and went into it with my eyes open - and a wallet full of 22,000chf worth of receipts from the last 3 years.   
It has relatively high KMs (120,000), has had a hard life (boat club) but has had a new engine, gearbox control unit and a great deal of suspension components.   
In my hands the left exhaust gas recirculation valve is a little sticky (but is technically covered by warranty) which puts the car into limp mode - which a restart corrects (even at 130kmh - neutral - ignition off and back on - drive  ). Fuel economy is 11l/100km in mixed driving - which isn't exactly great for a diesel - albeir breathed on to 223ps/550nm   
Saying all that, it is however a magnificent piece of machinery. It is utterly regal and relaxing on the motorway - up to sensible cruising speeds. It will tow huge loads without breaking sweat. The interior feels bulletproof (except for the stereo buttons - known Disco and RRSS issue). The seats are excellent and the stereo (Harman Kardon Pro Logic) exceptional. It is roomy for 5 but as Carlos says not great for luggage space 7 up. Equipment levels are very good and the leather feels like leather. It also feels reassuringly British    
Despite the issues I wouldn't hesitate to buy another. And comparing against a friends experience with 2 XC90s - I wouldn't call the Disco unreliable!!

Just to add a little more detail...   
A UK (or other non-neighbouring country) qualification (ICC with CEVNI) is valid here if 
a) you are a tourist and not resident in CH and 
b) technically for the first 12 months you live here (analagous to the driving licence) 
[Having said that, I don't know of any boat rental outlets that will rent out boats without a Swiss ticket]   
It is NOT valid if you take it after you became resident in CH - the same goes for any other country's qualification - even the neighbouring country qualifications can only be swapped for a Swiss ticket if you acquired them before you moved to CH or while you were resident in that country for a minimum of 12 months.   
It's why I had to do my D-Schein from scratch despite holding a commercial Yachtmaster ticket and instructor ticket.

Just wanted to give all of you the exciting conclusion to this adventure!   
The passes arrived in the mail today, which is exactly when they said they would.  That was good.  From here though, things went a little bit to pieces.   
The nice lady at the BLT said I should be able to hold up my pass to the machine and I would be able to pay at any green tram ticket thing. I did that.  The amount came up - it was wrong.  The price it wanted me to pay was 30 CHF more than what was on the pay slip - it wasn't taking into consideration my 30CHF new resident discount.  I'm thinking now that the 30CHF discount is just a skill test - can you actually work your way through the system and get the discount?  Read on!   
So I marched up to the Post Office, went in, got my number, waited.  They told me I could pay this annual pass slip there but not with my American debit card.  I had to get cash.  Ok.     
Out I go to the cash machine.  In I come back, get my number, wait.  Here is where it gets hard.   
The guy at the Binningen Post Finance takes my pay stub and tells me it is wrong and puts a big, fat stamp on it saying it's the wrong price for a tram pass, voiding my hard-earned payment slip.  Rats!  I say but wait, it's the right amount! He says, no, it is too much.  They are making you pay a full year but it only a half year.  No matter what I say, he won't let me pay it.  Ironic, yes?  So he tells me I have to go to Heuwegge to sort it all out.   
Off I go to the tram.  Get off at Heuwegge.  Wait in line behind a shed load of Aussies all on field trip of some sort, all wanting some kind of weekly pass.  Wait.   
Again, have I mentioned that they are super nice and helpful at this office?  The lady takes one look at my voided, special price ticket, asks which post office did this and hops on the phone.  It's vigilante justice, Swiss style!  She explains to me that this is a special price and now the dimwad (she had a cool word, I wish I remembered it) at Binnigen post had ruined it all for me.  Ruined it!  But she was going to ruin him for being such a twat.   
Needless to say, after first telling me that she wouldn't be able to help me because the guy had wrecked my discount pay slip, she got it to work!  I wish I knew how to say "I love you for kicking ass and getting this done for me!" in Swiss Deutsch.  She was awesome.     
And, at the end of it all, I have my annual, pro-rated, discounted Tram pass!  Watch out Basel!  Here I come!
Pay it and get it over with, that is the way in CH.

I recently sold my motorcycle to someone in France and the process was straightforward enough.

As an insulin dependant diabetic I had to be certified OK to drive every few years in the UK. Now with a Swiss license I have to get a form filled in by my doctor every year to confirm I am still fit to drive. This is never a problem, just time for the appointment, cost for the doctor's time (which, since it is a medical exam I would get done twice a year anyway so the insurance pays) and CHF100 to the Kanton (Zürich in my case) to pay for the admin. May be different in Vaud of course.   
Initially when I filled in the form to exchange the UK license for a Swiss one, I had to admit to the medical condition and was sent straight off to my doctor with a form. x years left on your UK license doesn't count and UK doctors won't be accepted by the Kanton to fill in the form anyway (here in German).   
It's not too much of an issue if you are fit to drive, just takes some time & effort. The only annoying part is that as soon as they agree you are fit, they send you the form for the next year which needs to be filed and remembered!

If you are not a mechanic and you have an old car which is called up for an MFK test, you have a number of options: 
1. Ask the your garage (or a number of garages) for an estimate of the costs of preparing it for an MFK. 
2. Take it to the MFK first and if it fails, request estimates for fixing the problems according to the failure list. 
3. Simply ask a garage to prepare it and take it through the MFK for you. But only if you trust the garage and your car is in reasonable condition. This is what I used to do but I don't necessarily recommend it.     
If the car is not in reasonable condition, you may find it is not worth the cost of taking it through the MFK.

I'm on the same boat as you, also doing my motorcycle and car license at the moment. Also looking for an English motorcycle instructor in Schaffhausen. I don't know how old you are, but if like me you're over 25 you need:    
-  The first aid course (I've already completed this, there are a few people who offer it in English in Zurich)   
-  Theorietest (when you apply for the Lernerfahrausweis tell them you need English and you can do it in Winterthur)   
After those two you get your L plates which are valid for 4 months   
-  Vehrkehrskunde course      
- 12 hours riding lessons (this extends your L license to 12 months)   
Within the 12 months you can take the test. I want to do it ASAP so I can ride outside the country.    
If you're over 25 you can get a 750cc right away, even on L plates. Let me know if you have other questions.   
edit: If you already have a car license you can get a motorcycle learner license right away and don't have to do anything besides the riding lessons before you're allowed to take the riding test.

- Reliability differences between major brands much less an issue over past 5 years; go with the used car with best documented service records versus a particular brand (but I'd still stay away from French makes, and lean towards Japanese if you aren't the vigilant type on maintenance intervals)
