- Look with autoscout24.ch or autoricardo.ch; I'd avoid the super dealers (like the one west of Uster)  If you do go to these, make double sure (in writing) that auto has "Unfallfrei" history 
- Even though you want to stay under SFr 10k price (very doable), spend extra SFr 100 to have independent mechanic look at it for obvious engine issues (esp. leaks if recently cleaned), brakes and linkages, frame or repaint work, etc. and make passing this check a condition of buying the car 
- Maybe be flexible on the sliding door, if not needed for handicap access?  We did just fine with baby seats and small children with wide rear doors on crossovers/small SUVs.

If it's any consolation I don't think that many drivers get through their driving careers without having a major smash at some point. The most important thing here is that nobody was hurt.   
I've had a couple of write offs that weren't my fault, and a couple of minor smashes that were. After the initial shock wears off, and the anger that you're now without a car subsides, you get over it pretty quick.   
It does sound as if you hit the brakes, the wheels locked and then you ended up possibly aquaplaning. The truth is you were too close, but what I will say in your defense is that the majority of drivers do not know how close too close is, and even if you do know and stick to it on a motorway then some other driver will probably jump into the space you've left - you can't win.   
If you drive an older car without all the modern assistive technology (in fact even if you do drive a modern car) then it really can pay to take a days skid pan training where you'll learn some valuable techniques in terms of how to handle a car in the wet, and how to identify when it's out of shape and what to do about it. Some of the things you'll learn are not immediately obvious at all, but when used correctly can really make a difference. It's also bloody good fun    
Anyway I hope you can soon put this experience behind you.

I would say this one was the most important one for me to focus on.  In South Africa we always have an indication on the road or a sign if you need to stop or yield at an intersection.  But in this case you could think you are on the main road (since it is bigger than the intersecting roads, and you are going straight, not turning) but you have to yield to the right.  That is strange if you are not used to it.  In short, in an intersection when the road from the right does not have a stop line or these triangles indicating they have to yield, you have to wait for cars from the right.     
I suppose the more official way to know whether to yield or not is to see all 'Main Road' (yellow and black sqaure on its side) and 'no longer Main Road' signs and know when you are the Main Road or not.  But since you can miss them, I looked at the road markings of intersecting roads.   
Good luck.

OK, I am able to report back on the whole thing now I've done it both ways.   
The cabins are very reasonable - Club 5 gives you two sets of bunks and a single bed/sofa running between the bunks.   
The room's about 4m x 4m.   
You have two windows, coffee-making facilities, a lightly-stocked minibar and a small flatscreen TV.  It has HDMI on it, I don't know if you can switch to that source if you bring your own player.   
Your bathroom is a wetroom with basin, shower and WC.   
You can tell how long it is since renovated because you still use keys on these ferries (I used both).   
Onboard you have the usual things - top level (blue) has a quieter bar plus the cinema - middle level (red) has the bar, disco, shopping - lower level (green) has the two restaurants and a children's play area.   
It's all reasonable, clean, staffed with decent people.   
The Zeebrugge/Hull route is quiet, I've been on Rotterdam/Hull crossings with lots more people and lots more cars and trucks.   
It was also about £200 cheaper than the corresponding crossing from Rotterdam.   
I can offer two Club experiences from Rotterdam crossings to compare with.  The simpler cabin takes 5 people but has a double bed with a bunk above plus a pair of bunks on the opposite wall - the cabin's about the same size on both ships.   
The best Club experience I've had was a corner suite (Rotterdam) with lots of space - a living room, a bedroom and an entry hall (plus of course bathroom).  If I knew how to book this again, I would.....!  I think they're called Club Suites and they're only 2 bed though.....

Nearly all of the trams in the Zurich network (the exceptions being the #10 and #12 to the Airport) stay within the city limit and can be accessed using the "1-2 Zone" fare.  So a day pass (assuming you don't have a 1/2-fare card) will set you back CHF 8.40.  As others have noted, there is no 1st class section on the tram -- so you only need a 2nd class ticket if you are planning on staying on the trams/buses.   
It's worth pointing out that parts of Zollikon are easily walkable from the last stop on the #4 tram (Bahnhof Tiefenbrunnen), but other parts are not.  So check and make sure that where you are going is walkable from there -- otherwise there are buses and trains that can take you further into Zollikon, but you will need a 3-zone ticket to do that (CHF 13.20).

Well now your car is running, go and buy a decent battery, if you wait until it stops again, then the Ford garage will fleece you. Your battery is 5 years old, it is a decent age and should be replaced soon.    
As I half explained, the electrodes in a modern battery is not a lead plate, but a paste of lead powder pushed into a frame. Over several years the paste falls down to the bottom and shorts out the cell. When the car moves, the vibration may cause the pile of silt to move, but it is very certain the battery will fail again very soon.  
A) Look in the car handbook for the battery rating Ampère/Hour Ah.  
B) Look also which way the battery is connected, draw a sketch for where the red and black terminals are.  
C) Look at how the battery is bolted to the car frame, often the black plastic has a "foot" which the clamp uses to keep the battery in one place.  
The above will help you choose the correct battery.    
Maybe just take the car to a small local independent garage, and ask them to fit a good make of battery.

There's still Military taxes to pay.    
Tom

I imagine that the absolute nature of the offence, that is not giving priority to a pedestrian, was to remove the possible defence for the motorist that the pedestrian "did not signal his intention to cross the road" and where proof either way would be more or less impossible.   
As a pedestrian, I have, incidentally, witnessed two potentially nasty incidents on a pedestrian crossing in Thun in the last few years where the car driver was seriously at fault.   
Incident 1 
It was evening and there was a crossing by a roundabout. A driver approaching the roundabout stopped for my wife and I, and we crossed to the middle Island. There was another car approaching the opposite end of the roundabout at some speed, but we reasoned there would have been enough time to cross the second section of the crossing comfortably, so we began crossing. To my horror, it became clear that the driver of this second car, an older woman, had  not even seen the roundabout, let alone the crossing,  and was driving as if it were a straight road. So we were forced to run to complete the crossing in safety, watching as her car was thrown up into the air as it mounted the raised central island of the roundabout landing more or less on the part of the crossing which we had just vacated. It took another 60 meters before she brought her car under control.   
Incident 2 
On an another occasion, this time in broad day light, again my wife wanted to use a crossing, one with no island in the middle. There was a car coming on our left, quite fast, but we still had plenty of time so began to cross. Now, from the other end of the crossing, a father carrying one child and with another small child by his side started to cross and we all neared each other more or less 2/3 of the way into the crossing. The car driver made no attempt to slow down, probably reasoning he would have plenty of time to cross the section that my wife and I had just vacated before the father would get anywhere close. However, the small child previously at her father's side (and who the car driver had probably not previously noticed) suddenly ran between my wife an I into the section of the crossing which the car was just about to enter. The father ran and dragged her back just as the car was speeding by with maybe one or two seconds to spare.

I know that you shouldn't get used to the high standards of Swiss public transport and then find fault with other places, but let me pass on this Xmas anecdote -   
A friend had a coach ticket from Nottingham to London.  We arrived at the coach station in plenty of time, and a large display in the waiting hall was showing all departures.  All seemed well except for one thing - the display showed departure time/destination/bay number for all departures except the London coach which had no bay number.  This was a day when storms had disrupted travel in the south of England, and my friend said ok, there must be a delay and that's why they didn't allocate a bay number yet.  Well it seemed reasonable to me too.   
Time gets closer to the departure time.  Still no bay number, also no announcement.  So we go to the ticket office, queue up for service, and manage to get served just before the scheduled departure time.  My friend asks why there is no bay number for the London coach.  'Oh' says the agent, 'that's a different coach company and we don't put the bay numbers on the display, but you want bay X'.  Got to bay X about 15 seconds after the coach had departed.  Now you might say that this is at least a bit understandable if the bay numbers change from day-to-day and would require someone to do daily entry of the information.  But it seemed pretty clear from the agent and from the timetables posted at the bay that bay X was the regular pick-up point for the London coach.  It's just that no-one wanted to put it on the main display in the waiting hall.   
And that is why I think the Swiss should run the world's public transport...

So, to finish off the story we decided to go with the easiest option. We borrowed a set of garage plates (the one with the U that can be put on any vehicle to move it from point A to B) and last Friday we drove up to Aargau to see the car.    
The car checked out so we went with the owner to the AG vehicle services centre (very nice by the way). There we signed the sales contract we had prepared, paid the CHF and he then cancelled the grey card on the car and gave it to us. The card is stamped cancelled. He kept the plates as they were also used for a second vehicle.   
We then dropped him off at his office and took the plates off the car (in CH, once you cancel the grey card, you have until midnight to get the car where you need it to go). We then put on the garage plates and drove the car home and parked it (important that if a car does not have plates it must be on private property or you will be fined). We returned the garage plates to the garage.   
Then we organized the insurance on the car (the insurance person enters the details in the VD vehicle service system so they have them when you arrive). We went to the local centre in Lausanne and cancelled the plates on the old car and transferred them (on paper) to the new car.    
A reminder, if we had had the old car with us (we did not) we would have been able to drive it home with the cancelled gray card and plates (until midnight same day). We left there with a grey card for the new car. The whole thing took 10 minutes of waiting and 5 minutes with the paperwork. At the same time they automatically cancelled the upcoming inspection on the old car.   
Since the old plate was the square version, we decided at the same time to order new plates - front and back (long version). In VD, it costs CHF 30 per plate to get new ones. It takes about 2-3 weeks. They mail them to you and you mail or drop off the old ones.   
Then we were left with the old vehicle (without plates) that we sold "as is" to an exporter.    
The new car goes in for a service on Monday so we know it is ready for the winter.   
Thank you all again for your input.

Before I went on vacation last month I looked up the websites of park n fly (based on the recommendation here) and also this one:         
I did not choose park n fly because it says that when you arrive, you still have to take a shuttle to your car (valet service is only for departure and not arrival).   
So I used airport parking instead: 
-Drive up to the departures area near check-in 2 and park your car at one of the short term car parks. Pay Fr.2 for the car park (for 15 minutes) 
- drop off your keys at their counter which is next to the info counter in check-in 2. Someone will drive your car away. 
-when you come back, pick up your keys from the same spot. 
-your car is waiting for you near the rental car offices in parking 3.   
The only small disadvantage is that if you have a lot of luggage, you still need to schlepp everything to parking 3 when you get back. On the other hand, with park n fly, you still need to put all your luggage into the shuttle, yada yada...   Price wise, it is only very slightly more expensive than parknfly.

post: I suspect this topic has never been covered before - and although it is unlikely to pop up again I thought I would be community spirited and post a guide to how to obtain a WagenPass       1) Application form   2) 2 * photos   3) FIA Homologation Number       1)   a) Go to the Auto Sport Suisse website -    b) Goto Formulare   c) Download the Antrag for Technischer WagenPass     2)   a) Ensure you have the right photos   b) One photo taken from the front left showing the front 3/4   c) One photo take from the rear right showing the rear 3/4     3)   a) Good luck trying to find the number you need on the FIA website.   b) Check instead    http://www.fia.com/sites/default/files/regulation/file/HomologatedForms-SortedByMake%26Model-2010.pdf  Then what? 1) Fill out the form. 2) Scan the form 3) Email to the ASA the scanned form and photos 4) Ask for them to send you an Einzahlungschein 5) Pay the 80chf 6) Wait to receive the pass in the post (it will take about a week)  The pass is an A6 size booklet. Naturally the cover is red, inside the front cover are the 2 pictures of the car (cropped to size) - and the a sheet outlining the FIA Homologation.  Then you have a load of pages for the organisers to fill out the details of the races the car participates in.

Fondue cheeses are traditionally Vacherin, Gruyere, Apenzeller, Emmentaler (But actually you can use any cheese you want, I think Grumpy is promoting a Cheddar variety), Additional you would need garlic, schnapps (Kirsch is traditional), a dry white wine (but cider is also an option), maybe cornstarch.   
You can mix the cheeses if you like (different kinds of chesses, or different variety of the same cheese) or use them solely (AFAIK Emmentaler is never used solo). For ex. the famous Moite-Moite is half Vacherin, half Gruyere.   
For dipping you can use bread, but also mushrooms, pear (preserved or fresh), banana, cooked potatoes etc.    
When you have nearly finished your Fondue but you are still hungry crack an egg into the caquelon and stir it into the melted cheese.    
If you are lazy you can also use a pre mixed package. If you are really lazy and you really do not care about taste you can use the microwave stuff.

If you buy a car from a private seller in Germany, he will not charge you 19% VAT, in fact, he won't charge you any VAT at all. So nothing to claim back at the border.

Hi Poot - free advice as short as I can make it  1) with SFr 5k, you want to buy good service records and condition, not brand  2) If you have time and patience, buy from private party (ricardo auto or autoscout24 dot ch)  3) ideal to buy above 100k km/"Zahnriemen" change, but below 150k km  4) buy smallest engine/PS you can, lowers licence and fees  5) if you can drive clutch, go with it for lower risk and cost  6) I'd go Japanese, avoid Audi/VW/BMW etc since any repairs at all will be major $$$ 7) on insurance, go bare bones minimum, no collision, no hail damage, etc  8) get a TCS policy, worth it's weight in gold  9) if deal doesn't include winter tires, replace with 1 set "all season" unless you go in mountains a lot 10) don't forget you only have SFr 4.5k to give for car, need rest for taxes, licence, highway vignette, etc. 11) if buy from dealer, make sure in writing it's "Unfallfrei" and not repaired accident car 12) spend extra for A/C, you'll want it  Good luck!  PS stay away Saab, I love them (had 3) but you will have problems and service/parts can be problematic IMHO

I've been wondering for years...

.... and the story continues...   
I called my insurer and with the Stammnummer provided in the 13.20A document from the customs office I got a Insurance proposal. (This proposal is notified by the insurer to the Strassenverkehrsamt directly without you doing anything)   
Then I went with: 
1.-EU Tech specification for the bike. 
2.-EU Street Permit 
3.-13.20A Document 
4.-Insurance policy went directly from the insurer 
5.-The bike is still insured with my EU insurance. And I guess is needed..   
to the Strassenverkehrsamt to get an Appointment for the MFK. 
They told me that there were some information that was not present in the EU Tech Spec document of the bike so I had to go to an Authorized Engineer to fill a document called "Selbsimport". And they gave me a paper with the MFK appointment.    
The Authorized Engineer (Don't need to be one from the official dealer of your brand in Switzerland, I tell you that, because I did it in a not Oficial Garage) will fill out the document/date/sign. You most likely need to pay for them to fill out the document but they didn't charge me anything for it. I would like to suggest to buy the registration plate holder to them if they are so kind not to charge you anything  .   
.... and the time goes by....   
Day before the MFK.... Clean your bike!!!   
MFK Appointment. 
1.-Be on time or earlier  
2.-Get eveything in good shape (all the docs you got). 
3.-Let them do the rest. 
4.-After a successful MFK go to the Strassenverkehrsamt offices and show the papers filled out by the Strassenverkehrsamt engineer 
5.-Get your plates and your swiss bike documentation 
6.-Put the plate into the plate holder 
7.-Buy a Vignette (and stick it under the seat) 
8.-Enjoy the bike   
My bike is in Switzerland. NOW I am here!!!!    
I has taken more than a year and a half, but today the sun shines.   
I hope this is useful for anyone else...   
juisjuis.

Is this mis-information day??   
The answer is: it all depends on the 4wd system. Volvo, along with a great deal other companies, use a Haldex system. In normal driving this channels 100% of the torque to the front wheels. When slip is detected a clutch slips some of the torque to the rear axle. In the Haldex 4 system (as first used by Saab in their XWD cars) there are further clutches either side of the axle differentials allowing upto 85% of the torque to be transferred to a single wheel.   
Any VAG car that has 4wd and a transverse engine will use HALDEX and not QUATTRO.   
BMWs x-Drive system has a normal distribution of 40/60 (front/rear).   
Nissan's system is even more clever - the locked 2wd isn't actually locked - and will transfer to the rear under extreme slip. Automatic mode will shuffle upto 43% of torque to the rear axle - and 4wd mode locks the ratio at 57/43 - which is the weight distribution of the car.   
The biggest bonus of the modern 4wd systems is the HILL DESCENT CONTROL. Controlling and stopping a modern car (1600-2000kg) on a steep slippery descent can be tricky - HDC takes over and can hold your speed at 16kmph leaving you to focus on steering.   
9 years - used chains twice!

A bit late but I just found this topic...   
To get a motorboat licence you will need to first pass a theory exam then pass a practical exam on the lake.   
The theory exam is 60 questions and the pass rate is 56. You can learn the theory from the free handbooks given out by the SCAN or better still buy the interactive CD for Fr 79.00 (see  ). I don't think you can do the exam in English, but ask the SCAN (maybe they changed the rules).   
Next, the practical exam must be taken within 18 months of getting the theory (otherwise you have to do the theory again!).   
My advice: Take private lessons so you get 100% of the time in charge of the boat. Private lessons are around Fr 90 / hour and you are going to need at least 10 lessons.   
Finally,   a list of all recognised instructors around Neuchatel. I recommend Philippe Marc Martin at Nid du Crô, he taught me and is a fun guy.

Well, it's horses for courses, really.  An intra-Europe trip on BA, in economy, will cost you 18'000 miles round-trip, plus a flat fee of EUR30.  If you prefer to conserve your miles, you can do it for 9'000 miles round-trip, plus EUR50, plus the flat fee of EUR30.  Availability for these short-haul flights is generally pretty good, and this can represent a   saving on a flight like the OP has described, where there is little competition and tickets are expensive (EUR500-700)   
To fly from Europe to Australia, in business class, you need to spend 200'000 miles.  On top of this, you need to pay the taxes and fuel fees, which adds about EUR1'000 to the 'free' ticket.  Availability is limited, and you've got to be very flexible in your dates.  It's unlikely you'll be able to use the tickets at a traditionally busy/expensive time of the year.   
If I have a theoretical 200'000 miles in my account, I can have 22 short-haul intra-European flights and spend EUR1'760 in taxes and fees.  This represents tickets that would otherwise have cost me EUR11'000 - EUR14'000.   
Or I could have your J-class ticket to Sydney.  I'd be willing to bet that in the low-demand seasons, like where you could actually get an award seat, you could purchase a restricted, non-changeable business class ticket for under EUR4'000.  As an added bonus, you'd actually earn business-class mileage credit for this flight -- enough for at least four, and maybe as many as eight (depending on whether you're a BA Gold or not) -- additional intra-Europe flights.  And enough tier points to get you to silver...   
The economics are obviously different if you're flying on routes where you can routinely pick up cheap fares (eg, where there is competition from Easyjet), but if you're flying on a route where one airline has the monopoly, using miles instead of cash can leave you far better off, as the example above shows.

To break it down: 
0.8hr: 
to plug in diagnostic machine 
read the codes 
double check whether it a sensor that has failed OR the car needs an oil change 
perform an oil change   
0.25hr: 
removal and remounting of the plastics that protect the engine from below - 7mins off, 7mins on   
5l of oil 
oilfilter 
seal for the oil sump   
Individually nothing is excessive.   
Now here is the thing, you bought the car from Foitek, you have a relationship with Foitek, and Foitek offer a service pack (250chf for an oil change) - Foitek know that doing that you will buy another car from them - oh yes, you did.   
The other guys are just doing a service - a one off job.   
A couple of things to consider: 
200chf/hr is a main dealer rate - BMW is 260chf/hr - small garages 130chf/hr 
The dealer systems pre-define what quantities for what job - IE 0.8hrs or 5l oil for your car. You are within your rights to ask for the extra 0.8l of oil.   
Modern high grade oil is brutal - my advice is to buy it in bulk from reifendirekt and take it with you for a service.

Hey Vaudoise, I am also in the process of getting a license and will be going for the First Aid course this weekend. A few of my friends did the theory exam in English in Bern. The process to apply in Bern is this: Once you complete the First Aid course, you will need to write to the Service des Automobiles, expressing your desire to do the test in English and requesting them to get in touch with Bern for permission and a date. Service des Automobiles then contact Bern and you should receive a letter from Bern with a date for the test. This whole process could take from 4 to 6 weeks!  
I am not sure of the cost of the theory test, but once you complete the theory, you will get a Leaner's Permit and will need to do a 'sensibilisation' course with a qualified instructor. This course if for 8 hours (4x2 hours). After this, the number of lessons you need will depend on how long you take to feel comfortable enough to go for the practical test.  
If you need a sample of the letter to be sent to Bern, please let me know. I can email it across to you.    
Good Luck

post: Since you bought the car two years ago, you don't have to worry about the CO2 tax. The tax is only due on imported cars that are new or within six months of the first registration abroad.

The international agreed law that permits visiting vehicles to drive in foreign countries (outside of the EU) requires that the vehicle maintains a road legal status in it's country of registration for the duration of it's stay in the foreign country.   
Whenever I ship one of my British registered vehicles to the USA I get it MoT'd and retaxed a few days before it is loaded on to the ship. I surrender my UK insurance policy to my British insurer and they give me a partial refund. Marine freight insurance starts at the dockyard and a foreign visiting vehicle policy starts when it arrives in the USA.   
Technically, surrendering my UK insurance means that the vehicle is no longer road legal in the UK. However, British insurers insist that only one insurance policy can be on a vehice at a time and the Customs & Border Patrol in the US only usually check that I have a valid UK tax disc displayed and that my US insurance is valid. My US insurer requires the MoT to be valid as in the event of an accident, a document check is guaranteed.   
How does this apply to Switzerland? Well, if your MoT, road tax, or insurance expire on your British registered vehicle it is no longer road legal here. If your road tax expires but your MoT and Insurance are still in force, you can contact DVLA for one. If your, MoT runs out, you either have to reregister the car in Switzerland or transport it back to the UK by truck to get it retested.

Hi All,   
I just wanted to give you some info, which might save you some money plus the hassle of going back and forth.   
I wanted to convert my license  to a Swiss one, so I followed the known procedure. Since my original license is written in a non-Swiss language (not English too), I was supposed to provide a certified translation of the license.   
I found a Swiss translation company, who charged me 108 CHF (the cheapest quote that I received). After sending back the license with the Swiss legalized translation, the Zurich Strassenverkehrsamt replied saying that they only accept translation made by the embassy of the issuing country in Switzerland, or they do the translation themselves through a translator costing between (80-200 CHF). I later contacted them, they said that these are the rules at least for Zurich, and they dont know the exact cost because the translator determines this on his own AND you would only know after the translation is done!   
So, the cheapest thing for your is to translate it at your respective embassy in Switzerland.   
Goodluck!

There's no expert like a garage or the TCS. Just take the car there (previous appointment required), pay a sum of money (50-150chf, depending), and get back a detailed report which no bring-along friend could ever give you.   
The only case where a bring-along friend helps is a "first view" of the car, assuming you (like me) take more than one viewing to decide. A skilled friend could then rule out lemons on the spot, potentially saving you the garage test fee and time.   
Finally, it would help stating what car it is: make, model and year. Different people know different cars and have different tools to check them (e.g., if you were buying say a VW Sharan up to 2004, I could maybe help you with a check of stored fault codes and such).

Oh dear.   
Never, ever, *ever*, travel with your passport anywhere other than on your person (in a reasonably secure pocket, or a money belt or whatever).  Leaving it in your bag is asking for an entirely avoidable problem.  Hotel safe, maybe, but definitely not in my bag.   
Your passport is, because of the hassle factor, the most valuable thing you travel with.  Not your CHF 2000 laptop, your passport.   
FWIW, though, it's another reason why I hate the nasty double-deck IC trains in CH (quite apart from the lack of seat width and legroom and the tiny windows in a country whose rail network's big strength is the view out of them).  I prefer my luggage in an overhead rack above me.

I imported a Lotus Excel which I bought from Lotus in 1989 (was chief engineer's car). I had the car in France and brought it here when I moved in 1991. I had no problem getting it licenced after an inspection at the Strassenverkersamt in Zurich. They checked it out against the specification and told me to get the speedometer changed to kilometres. The inspection was not expensive and I drove the car on Wechselnummer plates that I shared with my wife's car. Insurance was also reasonable.   
I also brought a BMW motorcycle that I purchased in the US. I rode it a couple of times here and then sold it for more than I paid because it was a 1000cc model that was not sold in Switzerland. The Swiss back then restricted motor size for the model to 800cc.   
Things may have changed in the interim, but my experience was painless.

I have discovered an anomaly using ticket machines near where I live. I told the BLS railway station staff and they said they knew about it and maybe a change will come. (I posted here rather than starting a new thread, as it is obscure)    
If I travel by car from Solothurn to Murten, the route takes me via the autobahn and is 68 Km long. If I should walk the route it would be only 48 Km,    (Click on car and then on the man ikons)   
Similarly there are different rail routings, which come at different prices, and buying the wrong (Cheaper) ticket can bring a fine!    
From Solothurn there are 3 routes, via Bern is the longest but fastest.  
Via Lyss is the shortest but slowest. 
Via Biel and Ins is the cheapest.    
When using a ticket machine supplied by the   at Solothurn, there is no option to buy a ticket & travel via Bern. The touch screen does not offer the via Bern option. I have to buy a ticket to Bern, and then a ticket from Bern to Murten.  
When using the   machine at Solothurn there IS an option to select a ticket via Bern, which is the quickest, and furthest and most expensive route. 
When using the   ticket machine at Murten there is only the option of buying a ticket via Lyss.     
Infuriatingly the   machine offered me a ticket Solothurn-Biel-Murten using the tourist ship from Biel, a service which only runs after Easter and costs CHF 90.-- !    
In other regions of Switzerland there might also be a similar routing problem, be careful and study your ticket, and if it says via Timbuctoo, then make sure you take that route, otherwise you   be fined for being on a section of the railway you have not paid for.

For example; The D runs from Bel-Air in Geneva to Saint Julien (and onto Vitam-parc-Neydens on certain days) without needing to change buses, and you can also travel on as far as Valleiry by changing in Saint Julien on to the Dn shuttle bus. The 4 takes you across the french border at Perly and picks up there as well.  
Both buses are run by, funded and staffed by the Transports Public de Geneve.

What I did when my sis gave me her car:

I left Ch again and just turned around right after the border and when I arrived told the lady I wanted to import the car. The did all the paperwork and the car was "sold to me for 3k " which they changed to 3500chf which they believed is the value for the car and chf conversion. Did that and 3 weeks later I had the appointment to get the emmissions test en the day after the big test. (make appointment as it is someone special for imports)    
Papers needed:  
COC  :150 chf from bmw CH takes 2 weeks 
ALL paperwork from cars first to last registration 
Insurance paperwork   
get it tested , call insurance guy (set this up beforehand as all they have to do then is press enter and you are good)  
get plates and enjoy your new "free"car

Hi all,  
I just finished importing/registering my car and I thought Id share the experience. Some of the steps are identical to ones already mentioned by other members in other threads, but some are somewhat different so maybe theyll be of use to someone.   
My car is an Opel Astra 1.6 Turbo, 2007 model. All parts original Opel, nothing changed. Car was registered in Greece.   
Before moving to Switzerland, and after researching the forum, I collected all necessary paperwork that I could and translated it all to German.    
My car was financed partially via a bank loan, so the initial registration said full ownership withheld. I had to make sure to get another paper which said that I was now the full owner (process in Greece: first you get confirmation form the bank that you paid in full, then a paper from the dealer and then you take that to the relevant traffic authorities and they give you a dot-matrix-printed piece of paper, which they staple on the original registration!).   
 The papers I translated 
I entered the country January 2012. When my personal belongings later came over, around April, I had made sure to note on the 18.44 that my car (included VIN/chassis number on the form) would arrive later this year. The 18.44 original was kept (for that reason, apparently) by the customs, at Chiasso.    
I asked the customs broker who handled the importation of my belongings to get the original, stamped 18.44 for me last month, and he sent a copy but with the official customs stamp visible. The customs people told him that they were keeping the original, but that this copy was fine for the purpose of getting a 13.20 and importing the car. Note that the customs broker initially told me I had to drive to Chiasso, but when I said that I know people who did it locally, he proceeded to find and send me a copy.   
I had also ordered a CoC from eurococ.eu a while back. It cost 104 and arrived in around 3 weeks. However, its NOT an original (more on this below)   
My car entered the country about 4 months ago (August), brought over by a relativeand therefore he could not stop at the border and import it for me. Due to a lot of work, I delayed the importation, but the time came that I could not delay it anymore, and had to start the process    
I had arranged for a green card (international insurance) from Greece, and renewed it after it expired. The car was theoretically covered at all times.   
Steps followed for the importation:   
Went to the customs at Embrach (Embraport, building Z1, first floor). Dealt with a very nice young guy, speaking excellent English. He asked for the following  
Note that at some point he forgot I had given him a 18.44, so he told me I can fill one on the spot, for the purpose of importing the car. This may be an option for someone, i.e., if the original 18.44 is missing/is lost. He then saw the one I gave him, so we proceeded with that one.   
He did NOT want the CoC, my drivers license or the insurance green card, though I asked.   
What I got back, after waiting for around 40 minutes 
Next day I get, via registered mail, a letter from the STVA, with instructions on what to do to register my car! That was truly impressive   
Anyway, now to start the registration process. The main point here is that your car needs to pass an inspection (MFK), to prove that its up to Swiss standards, etc. You book an appointment with them to do the test (plan ahead, as some members quoted 6 to 8 weeks wait times!), but in order to book the appointment you need to do two things:    
First thing, arrange for insurance. I had already discussed with saint7uk a while back, but he could not start the process until the car was imported. Now that I had the 13.20, I informed him and sent him the Stamm number found on it. He sent a nachweiss to the STVA, proving that I had coverage, so I could then proceed to the second step   
Second thing is to get an abgastest (emissions test). Checked the local Opel dealer, and he could only book a test in 2 weeks! (I asked but how long does the test take? and he said 1 hour! I guess a good sign I was going to be charged a full hours worth of labor) Knowing that the registration appointment could take up to 8 weeks, and with time running out, I checked for alternatives.    
I called a local, smaller garage, and the guy spoke good enough English. Said I could come the next morning for the test. I went over the next morning, but he pointed out that I did not have the small booklet that they record the results on (abgaswartung document). I went to the Opel Dealer again, paid 37 CHF, got it in around 40 minutes. I had all my car papers with me, I believe they copied some data off the original registration (date of first registration, and VIN maybe)   
Next morning I go to the smaller garage again, got the test done, cost:60CHF (duration: about 5 minutesthey plug a handheld computer directly to the console/engine getting readings directly from the car computer). Wrote the results on the booklet, also put a sticker on the window (next test: in 2 years) 
Now I had fulfilled both of the preconditions for booking the appointment.   
While in the garage, I told the mechanic that I also needed a yearly service, a set of winter tires and wheels, a pre-MFK test (which would include a nice cleaning of car and engine) and that if he was willing to take the car to the test himself Id do all of these in his garage   He said he does that, and also took all my papers and booked the appointment for me. The appointment was set for a week later and he booked at Winterthur.    
The papers I gave him for the appointment were 
After making the appointment, he told me to bring him the original CoC  I had given him a photo copy only. But the original had a watermark printed on it saying no original, and he was worried it may not be accepted as an original CoC . I sent an email to the eurococ people, and they replied (the next day) that its an official paper they themselves get from Opel. Its not _original_, since the original CoC was issued when the car was manufactured (2007). So we took our chances.    
The MFK did not care apparently, and the car passed the test. I got the car back with shiny new Swiss plates on, new registration paper and new winter tires and wheels. The MFK told the garage guy that the CoC was indeed not original, but they issued the registration anyway. I was told to keep the CoC along with the abgas booklet and the registration in the car at all times.   
I then sent the new plate numbers to saint7uk, so he could proceed with insurance. Took a picture of the car with the Swiss plates, shared with friends and family ("achievement unlocked")    
Notes:

The battery is made up from several lead-acid cells. The terminals inside these cells are constructed from a net containing a lead paste. Over time the paste falls out of the net, to the bottom of the battery casing. When it forms a high enough little hill and it will short circuit the cell, resulting in a loss of voltage.    
If you jump start the car it can run on the lower voltage, but even after a long journey there will not be enough good cells to start the car. The short circuit effect can happen suddenly, and you will only notice when you try to start the engine using the battery. You can measure the battery voltage with a volt meter and see it is low.

In addition to what  said above, I'll share some of my experience from my time working with Volkswagen.  At the time I was working there, they had overproduced several models.  Rather than discounting the price of the new car (which could undermine overall pricing power as well as hurting the value of used cars), the company came up with a clever way of flooding their network with 'nearly new' vehicles that could be sold at a discount alongside 'new' vehicles, in a bid to increase sales overall.   
Staff (and contractors) were allowed to lease these cars at incredibly low rates -- I leased a Seat Ibiza for around CHF90- per month -- on the condition that they were returned after 3 months or 5'000km, whichever happened first.     
My boss, at the time, had a long commute of nearly 150km each way.  She would get a new car every few weeks as she hit the mileage threshold.  It seemed crazy, but actual the economics behind it (for VW's sales network) were very sound.

Personally, I think that the auto stop/start is fine if you're driving a hybrid which can get moving with electric power then have the engine kick later. But if you are sitting at an intersection, you need to be able to move immediately instead of waiting for the engine to "boot up".    
As a motorcyclist, you learn to sit at an intersection with the bike in gear and the clutch engaged, so that you can immediately move if a car coming from behind fails to brake in time. Sure, getting rear-ended in my Audi won't be quite as painful as getting knocked off my Suzuki, but if I can avoid the contact all together by rolling forward a few meters, I want to leave this option open. And not have to wait 1-2 seconds until the car decides that I might need the engine.

GT3 is not a Tesla rival.   
If you want to be pedantic you should be comparing an Elise to a Tesla. The Elise will return 40mpg on a steady cruise.   
Even the GT3 you quoted is good for 30mpg (9.4 l/100km) on a steady run.   
However, the simple CO2 calculation is rather simplistic view. Firstly, rising CO2 levels have typically been the resultant of a global warming and not the cause, and secondly, a high CO2 producing car is quickly outweighed by a car that travels a lot of Kms.   
A GT3 that does 5000km a year is going to pump out less CO2 than a family car (150g/km) that does 15000km. One is demonised, one is not.   
All cars kill kittens - and I don't see the Tesla to be any cleaner than any other.

Will you be living in Switzerland or France. Your current location is France so if you are living there you'll probably need to register the car in France unless there is a special arrangement for 'Frontaliers' (but I don't know anything about that).   
If you're registering the car in Switzerland then the first thing you need to do is organise insurance. You won't get a new 'carte grise' until you can prove to them that you have insurance. The insurance company can easily send details of your insurance to the registration office electronically so it should be pretty easy to sort that out today. The 'carte grise' from the owner will have all the info necessary for the insurance but the original owner should have already cancelled it (should have annule stamped on it). You won't be able to drive the car until you get the licence plates. 
All this is only true for Switzerland. I can't remember exactly how it works in France bit IIRC it was exactly the same procedure.
It cannot be extended. You have to get a new one. Only get one once you made up your mind and have a clear plan, because you may have to see a shrink before you get a third one.  .

This:    The problem is not that Switzerland is not part of the EU but as you rightly state that the letters CH are not part of the Swiss number plate ( ). Switzerland is free to come up with a new license plate design which follows the convention w/o joining the EU. (They may do shortly before Zurich or Berne will have more than 1 Million registered cars)       And as long as a Swiss car is only driven in Switzerland no CH Sticker is needed. And when a Iranian car which has IR as part of the license plate comes into Switzerland no IR sticker is needed. And when a German, French, or Belgian car w/o the blue stripe enters Switzerland the corresponding Sticker is   needed. But   nobody cares. (And as we will see later inside the EU too when such a car leaves its home country.)      The OP asked what laws applies to a Swiss car in a foreign country. 
You linked Swiss law that applies to foreign cars that enter Switzerland, how the hell does it apply to a Swiss car driving in a foreign country? Switzerland has (nearly) no jurisdiction on things happening aboard.   
Now here comes the funny thing. The law you linked to is actually not only Swiss, but Iranian, Belgium, and German law altogether. It is international law and known as the  , you can find   at the UNECE. See, nothing to do with the EU at all, but indeed with with Iran.       Why ruin the paint of the car for an event that is a) very unlikely to happen b) can be solved with a spare sticker from the glove box? I am sincerely sorry to hear about your bike being stolen biff, but even if you had one of "these stickers" (that no longer exist btw) you still wouldn;t be covered. A vignette only covers damages to others, so in case of theft you need to have a home owners insurance or a separate bike insurance that costs significantly more than a vignette.   
I would also like to note a few things. Firrst off, if someone removed a front/rear wheel from a bike then the bike was not locked properly it's as simple as that. Then, even if you have a lock and lock the bike properly (both wheels tied to the frame and to an unmovable object), if the lock is easily cut then a bike is still an easy target. So those cable or weak chain locks and almost any lock that costs less than 100 francs is next to useless to properly secure a bike with. What I'm trying to say is that of course bikes are being stolen, and most likely they are also locked, but that doen't mean that a bike is never secure since there are locks (and most importantly attitudes) that can make a bike pretty secure.

post:
My personal experience importing and registering a car from the USA to BaselLandschaft. This was also declared as part of my household goods, so I did not have to pay import duty.     
  Vehicle details: 2003 BMW 5 series with Xenon HL, autoleveling sensor, HL washer, 18" wheels and Kuhmo 245-40-ZR18 97W spec tires, DINAN strut bar.     
  1. replace yellow reflector HL lens with clear reflectors (piece of cake, done by myself) 
  2. Warning Triangle: purchased from Ebay for USD 15, fits like glove in the trunk where all the tools belong (If you own a BMW, you know there is a compartment in the trunk that you can store a few tools) 
  3. First Aid kit: USD 20 (this is optional in Switzerland, but is required in Germany) 
  4. Make sure there is no excess oil/fluid residue inside the engine compartment, the MFP people do look for leaks (big or small).  I maintained my own car way above and beyond, not a drop of oil/liquid can be found, the inspector was very surprised for a 9 year-old car. 
  5. If shipped with household goods, ensure that you detailed it in the 18.44 form. You will need this origianl form back from the shpping company. 
  6. Take off the license plates before you hand the car to the shipper, take the plates with you in your luggage (not in the shipment of the household goods).     
  1. First registration document, i.e. the vehicle identification card from the first time the car was registered (this is easy if you keep all your records and are the original owner. If you bought the vehicle used, please don't ask me how to get the first registration document, because I would not know. Sorry) 
  2. Vehicle owner's manual (put sticky on the pages that show the specifications of your car, e.g. weight, dimension, engine size, etc. The MFP will be more than happy to serve you if they felt that you have done your homework). 
  3. License plates      
  Any freight forwarder you want (whatever flows your boat). Cost varies. The shipper will tell you what you need to provide them (in general, the vehicle title and you need to general a EIN from the US federal government in order for you to export your vehicle. If you have to ship your household goods, you probably would have done that step already).     
  Depends on how you arranged for your shipment, you either paid to have the car deliver to your residence in Switzerland or you pick it up at the port. I chose to have the shipper deliver to my house. Make sure you get the 13.20A from the shipper. It has the Stem number that you will need in order to obtain insurance and to register.     
  This is the sucky part, there are not too many insurance companies will insure vehicles with foreign plates. Also things to consider is that when you try to register the vehicle in Baselland, the regulation requires you to have insurance from a Swiss company, i.e. not company from the UK, or elsewhere. For this,  I ended up with the big "Z", not the internet establishment, but the actual retail establishment and meet with the real insurance agent. Again, you don't have a choice.     
  Bring - 
  1. Original 13.20A form that has the zoll stamp and stem number 
  2. Original 18.44 form  
  3. Proof of insurance (the insurance company can send that electronically to the MFK ahead of time) 
  4. Obtain an appointment date for the MFP inpection     
  1. Get the Abgas document from your car brand's dealership. I paid CHF 125 for a BMW dealer here in Basel to prepare the AbgasDoc. The Abgas dokument is a requirement and you cannot avoid. 
  2. Wash the car. It is easier for them to inspect with a clean car than a car covered with mud and dirt.      
  1. Bring along your appoint sheet from the MFK 
  2. Bring the vehicle owner's manual, first registration document, 13.20A, and 18.44. 
  3. Show up 10 mintures before my appointment time. Your appointment will also tell you which lane you are supposed to line up. 
  4. Paid the CHF 240 fee and then patiently wait for your turn. 
  5. Cooperate with the technician. (for me, the tech was very polite and courteous)    
  They do check the car thoroughly, above and below, engine compartment, suspension, steering, wheels, brakes,  etc. The whole process took about 30 minutes and another 30 minutes for him to write up everything. At the end, my car passed with flying colors, and I was handed the documents back and was told to go to  the MFK to obtain the Swiss plates.   
  That was all. Not much drama. To be honest, I was worry about the 18" wheels and the strut bar, but the tech didn't seem to be picking on them.   
  That said. I was considering paying some company to register for me, but at the end, I could not find a company that would care to respond or would not charge you an arm and a leg. I called the MFK and emailed the MFP several times to get some clarity on the process. In general, they are happy to help. So, why not do it myself and save some really money!

Here it is how it works. I do bieve the solution is quite generic, so it might solve other problems as well in a similar way.   
You go to the station, and ask for the modification. They take your old pass, and give you a new one, with the new conditions (for me new zones, for instance), valid from the day of this action, or any date later (but not the original validity date). You pay for the new pass, and what is the key of the whole process is that they refund the remaining days of your old pass. 
My was valid for abt. for 3 more weeks, so I got refunded 81 CHF, and therefore paid 34 for a new monthly pass valid from today for a month (original price would be 115 CHF).

But seriously, when I had to teach myself, I found the best way to do it, is to give a bit more gas (till just before you hear the engine really revving), then ease off the clutch as slowly and gently as humanly possible. For the first few times, even if you are easing as slowly/gently as you think you can, ease it even slower. It takes time, and best not to do it in traffic, but once you feel it catching (ease EVEN more slower :P) then you can reduce the accelerometer to a comfortable start.    
And whenever you're not on the gas, have the clutch depressed.    
Maybe not the best methods, but it worked for me when I was 16, and stuck.

From my own experience, it's always better to buy your car from a dealership that sells the same brand. You're more likely to get a car that they have known for years, you'll almost always get a 12-month full warranty, whereas those places specialising in selling used cars tend to have "Quality 1" or something related (*). You usually have to go to the same dealership if something breaks, however.    
Here's my list:   
1. Same-brand dealership 
2. different brand dealership 
3. Larger "car discounts" 
4. Smaller independent garages 
5. Yard-sale type snake-oil sellers   
1. + 2. are usually ok, while 3-5 are usually crap. I've had so many bad experiences with 3-5 that I'll never buy a car from those places again.   
Unfortunately, you'll find no. 5 most frequently here in Switzerland. Stay away from these.    
Peter   
*) "Quality 1", "All-In" etc. aren't actual warranties. These are insurance policies. As such, they always carry deductibles (which can be extremely high, depending on your policy). Also, as these insurance policies actually make the garage you bring your car to pay 10% of the repair costs, they're not very popular among repair shops. I've been told many times by repair shops that they won't repair my car under Quality 1 "warranty" because of that. So while they're usually better than having no warranty at all, these insurance policies are worth a lot less than a normal 12-month warranty.

To answer your questions, France has a tax free buy back program for originally Non EU Residents (which I am - I'm Indian) who only plan to live in Europe for a maximum of one year for students only. Most European countries lets you rent the full one year - unfortunately Swtizerland being Switzerland only lets you rent 6 months. Some of these so called buy back programs are Renault Eurodrive, Peugeout Open Europe, etc.

It depends which office you go to - and probably which Canton you live in. We got the forms, filled them out, had an eye test at a local opticians & got the forms approved by the controle des habitants to confirm our residence information.  
We first went to the local offices of the Service des Automobiles et de la navigation in Aigle. We were due to leave on holiday within a few days so they suggested we went to the main office in Lausanne because they could print the licenses immediately whereas Aigle would have to send everything to Lausanne for processing - we did so and got our liceneses within about 30 minutes.    
To speed up the process we surrendered our right to a Category C licence - in the UK you used to get automatic right to drive up to 7.5 tonnes GVW with your car (cat B) licence. Here that is classed as a professional licence so you have to take a medical and get a police report of some kind - since we were in a hurry and have never used the category C we decided not to bother.

Once you'll have the plates on your car, the bill for the tax plus some registration fee will arrive soon. Don't worry.    
You can calculate the yearly tax  . Just enter the displacement of your car's engine in the upper box ("Hubraum in Kubikzentimeter") and click the "Berechnen" button.

The Eurotax is the reference in Switzerland and the garage will always pay you the lower end (or possibly less by inventing a few excuses) of the Eurotax range.   
Since you have to pay to use the Eurotax, you can have a look at sites like autoscout24.ch and see the prices of other cars of the same model and similar age/mileage (optionals have almost no influence on the price, only year and mileage are relevant). If you are selling privately you must lower a bit the price compared to a garage. If you are selling to a garage, when you half the autoscout price you are not too far from what the garage will offer you

Just finished reading some of your GCCE posts...it's nice to come across a kindred spirit! I'm also a fan of old Volvos, specifically the 240s. Other old tanks from the 80s excite me like the BMW 525i, Mercedes 300E, even the Passat for its design alone. There's a sweet spot in that era of car engineering...simplicity, quality, unpretentious materials. In the 90s, the manufacturers attempted to move upscale but the materials never quite held up over time. It seemed that luxury cars were built for the first owner, but never the second and third...especially Audis. I owned a Volvo 850 for a few years just before it started to fall apart in ways that the 240 would simply never suffer from.   
I would not hesitate to purchase another 240, but I'll never buy a used European car from the 90s on.   
Until I moved to Switzerland, I never owned a car worth more than $6500. Due to my contract it only made sense to lease, so I'm driving a wonderful car...a 2012 Mini Cooper S. It's the only car in my price range that I connected with on a soulful level. The BMW 120i that I tested was quite competent, but hardly engaging.   
My dream garage is a 1967 Land Rover IIA, 1998 Porsche 993 and whatever day-to-day car is necessary to do trips, etc. such as a BMW wagon.   
Best of luck with the 9-3!

After a little research I found the following information on admin.ch 
It's not conclusive, therefore I will look into it in more detail and report my findings.       
USE OF FOREIGN PRIVATE VEHICLES IN SWITZERLAND   
The temporary use of foreign private vehicles by persons resident in Switzerland is prohibited in principle. Concerning customs and road traffic legal notification obligations with regard to the use of foreign vehicles in Switzerland, experience shows that there is often uncertainty and confusion.    
People resident in Switzerland 
In principle, people who are resident in Switzerland are not allowed to use a foreign vehicle registered abroad in Switzerland. This also applies to vehicles which relatives or acquaintances from abroad allow you to use occasionally, for example.           
Vehicles of immigrants, foreign workers, students and interns 
When crossing the border, vehicles on which duty has not been paid must be declared for customs clearance spontaneously and without delay (principle of self-assessment).     
Immigrants may import and use their vehicles in Switzerland exempt from duty under certain conditions. Foreign workers, students and interns may use their foreign vehicles on which duty has not been paid in Switzerland. However, a customs permit is needed for this.   
Violations 
People who have not yet declared their vehicle to customs are requested to report to a customs office to declare their vehicle. Those who do not declare their vehicle for customs clearance will be liable to prosecution. In addition, a claim for payment of the import duties must be anticipated.     
Opening hours and addresses of customs offices 
Please note the customs office opening hours for the declaration (customs clearance) of merchandise. Declarations can be made from Monday to Friday during clearance hours; some customs offices are also open on Saturday mornings.       
The detailed opening hours are available in the list of customs offices.  
For merchandise, please note the customs offices or field offices that are marked blue/white or blue.   
Foreign customs administrations 
We are unable to provide information on foreign regulations. The opening hours and addresses, as well as other information from foreign customs administrations, are available at the following World Customs Organization link: WCO - National customs.   
Further information can be found in the right-hand column, including the fact sheets, which provide information on the most common cases.   
Additional information can be obtained from the customs offices and District Directorates of Customs. For questions to do with vehicle registration and driving licences, the vehicle licensing offices should be contacted (listed at  ).

Why only the corner of your eye?  If you're turning, you should be checking your mirrors immediately prior to making the manoeuvre.  If you're moving off after being stationary for a period, you should also be making a final check over your shoulder into your blind spot.   Signalling doesn't give you the right to make a manoeuvre - it just makes others aware of your intentions.   
The point I'm trying to make is that if you had had an accident, this is what the cyclist's lawyer would be saying.  You would have to convince a judge that you had checked all these properly immediately before beginning to turn, found them to be clear,   the cyclist managed to arrive from outside your field of view to next to your car within half a second or so.  I doubt you would win that one, I'm afraid.     
Even if the cyclist has made a poor decision themselves (which they clearly have in this case), it would be easy for his lawyer to claim that you had plenty of opportunity to make sufficient observations to avoid the collision.  The responsibility for ensuring safety is pretty much all in your hands in this case.

Dear EF,    
I read a lot of threads about purchasing cars, and some time ago, I was also looking for a car  - I had just moved to Basel in 2010.   
What I needed: 
a) family car 
b) spacious 
c) reliable 
d) low mileage 
e) within budget of 10,000CHF 
f) is somewhat 'stylish' to drive   
Having searched many websites like comparis and autoscout, I finally bought a car:     
Yes, I bought the BMW 525i from the Forum and this is what I wanted to report on buying an old car in CH i.e. by swiss standards.   
1) with 266,000km on the clock, I was a little nervous.  It has done 280,000 since I bought it, and is still going very strong. 
2) in 2 years, I have invested about 300 francs to get the door fixed ( it got jammed because my son poured water down the lock) 
3) the drive is still smooth, gives me 10l/100km. 
4) externally and internally, the car still looks slick..ok, so it not a new car, and is a 1989 model - but if well maintained, it makes me smile when I see it parked up. 
5)I paid 2000 CHF for the car. 
6) drove it to UK, and got a MOT check done whilst there - as my MFK is due at the end of the year - mechanic found it to be a very clean car for its age and was tempted to buy it from me!!   
So in small summary, the message is that for all those looking to buy a car, as long as you check the history, MFK, test drive, do your own checks ( download a list of checks from which.co.uk or other motoring sites), and a gut feel - it is well worth looking at the CH older car market - as you can pick up some great deals! very confident that it is better than what I experienced in the UK when buying a 2nd/3rd hand car.   
And of course, with the feedback that people provide on this forum for the cars that are posted, generally is worth reading ( not all the time), but it did help me in taking a mitigated risk when buying the car!   
there you have it! 
hope this is useful to some....and perhaps others have a positive story to share.  
Chippie.

if anyone has a zumo 550 on the bike you need to check your cradle NOW!!   
open the back of the cradle (4 screws) chances are if its been raining the circuit board is wet.   
there is a ribbon connector at the bottom of the board that links to the pins on the cradle. The ribbon cable can burn out if its wet.    
pull the brown retainer out and look at the ribbon for any arcing.   
That meants the zumo is not charged by the bike and the zumo can also be fried.   
dry it out and repack the mount with non-conductive dielectric grease.   
A new mount is €80 / 120CHF   
the zumo is rated as IPX-7 (1m underwater for 30 min) but the mount is not waterproof    
this happened to me last week in slovenia and meant a day trip to Graz to find a dealer that had a mount.

you can get tickets for any zone you like from a ZVV sales office. All you have to do is stamp them. You don't actually have to stamp them in the zone in which they are valid. So you can stamp them at the start of your journey for example. You can get them as individual tickets but also the multi-versions. Just forhet about the "Anschluss" bit. You're making things unnecessarily complicated by insisting on that. So for example if you frequently need zone 21, you by a "Tageswahlkartre Zone 21" at the ZVV or  SBB sales office or even one of the touch-screen machines. On a day you have to go into zone 21, you stamp this at the ticket machine at the start of your journey (or on the bus if it is a bus that has validators, check this before travelling though). It doesn't matter that the machine is outside zone 21 as the validity is defined by the ticket and time of validation, not the place of validation. You could even stamp it in basel or Lugano if you like, though it probably woudn't make much sense. The ticket will then cover you for a day, ie, cover you for the journey out and the journey home.   
For example, my GF has a Regenbogen for Zürich zone 10. Sometimes she catches the train from Basel to ZH airport, and catches a bus at the airport to Kloten. As you get more experience, you'll learn what speed feel appropriate given the driving conditions.  In general, for your driving test, I would concentrate on making sure that you are moving at approximately the same speed as the rest of traffic (without exceeding the limit).   
If the rest of traffic is flowing at 60km/h in a 60km/h zone, that's the speed you should be driving.  If the rest of the traffic is flowing at 60km/h in a 50km/h zone, you should be driving at 50km/h.   
The examiner will want to see three things:   
1) That you respect the speed limit 
2) That you can drive under control at an appropriate speed for the conditions 
3) That you are not blocking/hindering the progress of other traffic   
Good luck on your test.

All of the above. If you're going over for a few days, visiting friends and family in various parts of the country, you're going to need some form of transport while you're there, and the only realistic option would be to fly and hire a car. I've done this before, but even when the flight is paid with Air Miles, the taxes can still be significant, and car rental is never cheap. Oh, and parking at your home airport, or taxi costs too. So in some cases it may actually be cheaper to drive, yes (assuming two or more people).   
The offset of course is the additional time, but TBH if you've two drivers you can get to mid-parts of the UK within 12 hours or so - flying, while only taking an hour or so in the air, will require: getting to the airport, parking car, waiting at checkin, waiting in lounge, waiting for takeoff, waiting to disembark, waiting for luggage, waiting for bus to car rental, waiting for car to be made ready; all of which can take up to five or six hours out of the day, and that's before you start driving to your actual destination.   
Of course, if you live in a major city and are only going to a major city, it can be much simpler and cheaper than that, but that's where the advantages of driving lie for me.   
Oh, plus we'll come back with a Passat Variant full of proper thick 100% cotton John Lewis bedding, sausages, pork pies, Cadbury's chocolate, cheese and beer.

As far as I remeber, there is no limit on how far you are allowed to reverse. You just have to keep in mind, that while you are doing it everibody else has the right of way and that you are not allowed to impede traffic or to drive faster than 5 km/h (wlaking speed). If you reverse for more than 50m you have to change the side of the roads (ie driving on the same side of the road as if you were driving forward in that direction).   
Reversing is indeed a standard manuvour in Swiss driving tests, as it allows you to asses the controle the driver has of his car and his awarness, as it requires him to constantly check for oncoming traffic in all directions.   
This however is not performed on a main road, but rather on some minor road and the corners around one has to reverse are chosen such that there are no objects obstructing the driver's view.

edit: didn't realize this was an older thread...but I think it might still be interesting for some to see the breakdown of costs we had.  We could have avoided a few of those costs, like transport of the car to us from the port, but given we have 3 little ones and the smallest was just 3 months old at the time, we figured the cost of paying someone else to do it was less than the cost and stress to us if we did it ourselves!     
Excellent point by Caninsui about the type of permit one has - we didn't have that issue as we were moving to Germany at the time...anyways, here is my story    
We didn't import to Switzerland, but to Germany.  We were in a situation where we bought a car in Jan of 2009 and end of February we found out we were being moved (we thought the move wouldn't happen as we turned down an offer the Nov before).   
Anyhow, being it was in the throes of the recession, the place where we bought the car was not interested in buying it back.  And given the $ was so cheap then and buying cars in Germany was much more expensive, we brought it over.     
It was a MAJOR pain!  That was the most stress I had from the move...of course time heals the wounds and I don't remember it all, but here is a breakdown of costs we had at the time:   
ocean freight $1050 
insurance premium $600 (usually 2% of insured value, I think) 
trucking $475 (to take from my house in NY to the port, about 180 miles)   
total $2125 on the US side   
We then had a bill from Interfracht on the German side for 858 € on top of that    
unloading of container and taking to storage €325 
transport of car from Bremerhaven to Frankfurt area €290 
and some other various fees and charges bringing the total to 858.   
The cost of conversion to German standards was another 1500€ (to be fair, the guys were almost apologetic that it was so high as it is usually in the 800€ range).  We brought over a car that isn't sold here - VW Routan.  Parts are a pain...although since it is a sister vehicle to a Chrysler Grand Voyager, we are able to get it serviced at a Chrysler garage.    
Now, we do get many questions about the car as people wonder what the heck it is - and in the end it was cheaper than buying a new car here...but it was a hassle.  If I had to do it all over again I may have tried harder to get rid of it and buy a used minivan over here...

Any car will do, unless you live well out of town on the slopes of (one of many) a nearby mountain.  Downtown Geneva gets relatively little snow, a few days per year only.  But you MUST get winter tyres which significantly increase grip.   
7 seaters are quite common, Mazdas will be available, but they're not so common as  Opel Zafira, VW Touran, or Ford S Max which are easier to find (if buying second hand).  Look at autoscout.ch for an idea of what's available here and how common.  Don't let others panic you, traffic here is no worse than downtown Christchurch or similar.  Rush hour is slow, but drivers here are civilised and you'll get the hang quickly enough.  Parking spaces are small by US standards, but not by European standards.  Unless you're a nervous driver/parker you should be fine.   
Don't listen to those who say you can survive in Geneva without a car.  Without kids, if you're loaded and live close to school, maybe.  But for "normal" people with kids, unless you intend to keep the kids from doing extra curricular activities, clubs, etc. or are a real fan of public transport, you'll need a car.  In particular, public transport with impatient kids is not practical outside business hours in the Geneva suburbs.  However, if you live where your husband can commute without a car, you should be able to get by with a single car.   
Half booster seats should be fine for kids that age.  Check the TCS (Touring club suisse) website for the rules.   
Steve

I often see posts about mean ticket-checkers and big fines and wanted to share my positive experience and hopefully help people avoid a similar mistake.    
I sometimes comute from Zurich - Lausanne or Geneve and usually buy a day pass (68 CHF) to go there and back and use the local transit. This time I was staying multiple days so instead got a return ticket (69 CHF) and for convenience added the city ticket option (+4.4 CHF) for the metro. I didn't realize  .    
After a long few days I was finally headed home and the conductor came and said 'oh, you have kind of a   ticket' and explained it was expired. I thought for sure I was in for a fine and another ticket. However, he was SUPER NICE, explained my ticket, suggested other options, and let me go with a warning. Really lucky and everything worked out.   
Morale of the story is to be careful with the city ticket.

Oh yes, there's no doubting the beauty of it so long as you want either that convenience of are using the system that much.   
A GA costs 3100chf (I even had the famile version with children that reduced it 1700Chf and decided to ditch it!). A half-card costs 125Chf, which gives you half-fare on everything; the difference is 2975Chf. You need to be doing double that amount of travel  - 6000Chf equivalent to really justify it. And then with a half-card you can still get multi-journey and season tickets, as well the specials. Once you have the GA you don't bother with any fares. And this December the GA is increasing by 8% whereas ordinary fares apprently by 1.5%! Of course there are a few extra benefits with the GA as well. If one adult has one then one for their children 6- 16 only costs 12Chf/week.    
I have a bike pass @ 190Chf, a half-card @ 125Chf, a kinder pass @ 20Chf and six-trip tickets to my regular destinations; a lot more to carry right enough

I had a UK driving licence, downloaded the forms from my local Strassenverkehrsamt, filled them out and then rang the Verkehrsamt who gave me details of the nearest approved eye doctor for the medical (which you have to have if you are over 60). It seemed pretty thorough to me. I handed the forms and my UK licence in to my local Gemeinde and they sent them to the Verkehrsamt. I then got a call from them saying that since my old licence included the HGV driving option I would have to go for an extra medical if I wanted to retain the HGV component. I decided that having survived 40+ years of driving without needing to drive anything other than cars and the odd minibus, I would hardly be needing to do so in the future. I was sent a form where I had to renounce driving HGVs and got my Swiss licence in the post 10 days later. The whole thing was totally trouble free and local. The whole thing cost 200CHF, so 100CHF sounds like a bargain. Different cantons different prices I guess.

In December 2009, after 6 months wait, I took delivery of a new VW Polo (6R current model) 1,4 petrol with 7-speed DSG ( Direct-Shift Gearbox ) - essentially an automatic gearbox.    
All has been wonderful and with servicing every 30,000km or 2 years the cost to date has been CHF400.00 and repairs zero. And average 5.9l per 100km.   
With 35,000km on the clock and 24½ months of happy motoring, the DSG box went on the blink in the last couple of weeks.   
This involved the gearbox going into neutral while in 'D' and while driving. Once stopped and the engine restarted it clears. This happened only twice, but is understandably potentially leathal, especially in a tunnel or on the autbahn.   
A quick Google proved this, and all sorts of other problems, to be common with VW/Audi/Skoda models with DSG. Also getting satisfaction from either dealers and manufacturers appeared also to be just as big a problem.   
So it was with some concern that I check the car in at my local VW dealer (Autorama in Wetzikion (ZH)) where I also bought the car. After 24 hours and correspondence between Autorama and VW importers AMAG, they have agreed to replace the Metatronc box (the brains that drive the gearbox) free of charge (parts and labour). This is on order from Germany and will be done next week.   
Had I imported the car from Germany or bought at the likes of Autodiscount Uster, I wonder if I be so content. Autorama even cleaned the car inside and out while it was in for assessment...

As others have said, it's hard to give advice about half fare cards or general abonnements without knowing your precise plans...   
But to help you figure it out...   
Use the sbb site to work out the cost of your daily commute (note, it automatically assumes you have a half fare card). Then either work out how much you will spend a year (and compare to a yearly GA), or how much you will spend per month (and compare to a monthly GA). Then make your choice.  There you go!   
I have a GA (monthly, it's a little more expensive but I can't afford a lump sum... and this way after the first 4 months I could cancel it if I wished). I find that not only is it cost effective (for me), but also it saves time and stress. No need to worry about having bought a ticket, ever! It also means that I don't find myself sitting there thinking 'I'd like to go to such-and-such... but can I afford the train fare?'...   
Oh, and about buying the ticket online... if doing this on a mobile phone, make sure you don't confuse the online ticket   and the ticket you can buy on mobile phones. I was on the train the other day and someone had purchased an online ticket on their mobile, but a printable kind, not a mobile phone ticket, and hadn't realised the difference so hadn't printed it out... the inspector was not happy because he couldn't scan it.
