It is always better to look first at the official Government web site as well as asking questions on a forum because while many or most forum answers are the truth they are not necessarily the whole truth.   
Switzerland has accepted a large number of EU directives but not the Driving Licence Directive 91/439/EEC & Directive 2006/126/EC.   &   That means while it has arrangements to exchange EU/EEA licences for Swiss ones without tests   it does not follow EU law that allows you to drive at least until age 70 (in UK for example) on a (non-professional) licence issued by another EU/EEA state without ever exchanging it.   
(This does not apply to you, but others may find this useful: EU law does not require another member state to exchange a licence unless theory and practical (written and road) tests were taken in an EU/EEA country. So if (like my wife) you obtained your Swiss (or French, Danish, etc.) licence by exchanging it for a third country (USA, say), the UK will not exchange it for a UK one.   But once you have passed the theory and practical tests in any EU state the only restriction another member state can impose concern optical and medical tests, or those resulting from penalty points. Some of the current EU rules mimic American efforts to prevent drivers having been banned in one state (typically for DUI) from obtaining a licence in another. Meanwhile there are numerous fraudulent schemes advertised on the Internet for obtaining and exchanging EU licences: all are scams   -- which is not to say that driving schools and driving examiners, especially in some of the EU-8 countries, have not been suspected or accused of complicity in the corrupt issuance of licences to unqualified drivers. Also a scam, but at least one has a facially valid driving document and until and unless they catch the fraudsters one is able to drive. But this happens everywhere from time to time:   (California))   
As the Vaud driving licence web site points out   for foreign licences issued after 1 Dec. 2005 and less than a year before arrival in Switzerland there will be a probationary period. (But there is a 2-year probationary period in the UK anyway.   )   
In Switzerland where domicile is registered, as in most European countries, you can only get a licence (or in fact take a driving test) upon proof of registration with a commune. As the UK, Ireland and Gibraltar have no registration requirement for Swiss nationals and Swiss passports will not be stamped on entry, the EU law requiring 6 months' residence to take a practical test is enforced by the test examiner having the driver sign a certification on the test sheet. (To obtain a provisional (learner's) licence, holders of passports other than UK ones need to send them in to DVLA for inspection.)   
(As another aside; Switzerland, like all countries, makes driving licences available to diplomatic personnel without tests upon proof of prior licensing in another country.   In Switzerland such licences are unrestricted, valid for life. In the UK the DVLA use a supply of ancient little red booklets and the data page is marked "Diplomatic" and expires after 3 years without right of renewal.    
(There are at least 110 licence styles still valid in the EU/EEA/Switzerland   &   All those countries are now using a standard credit-card-size photo-bearing pink format for new and replacement licences.   From 2013 EU driving licences are supposed to be subject to renewal every 5 or 10 years, per Directive 2006/126/EC.   )   
For what it is worth: the pass rate for UK practical tests is mostly between 40% and 50%, depending on the test centre:   The rate is lower for drivers taking the test for the first-time. I think it is worthwhile hiring a driving instructor who teaches in the area of the test, for example Iseleworth (near London). Familiarity with the test routes is helpful (all are published; one is assigned one of the official dozen or so routes arbitrarily at the moment of starting the test).

Remember that the canton of Geneva is pretty tiny compared with ZH, so the whole of the canton is covered by Unireso zone 10. Looking at the map there are various outlying zones covering bits of France and a bit of Vaud (unsurprisingly, as the subsidy regimes etc. will be different.)   
There are tariff unions covering most of Switzerland - some are a little newer than others, some are more zonal than others in their outlook, but they all follow roughly the same model of delivering a single timetable / tariff structure / fare collection system across the multitude of companies that operate services. Zürich's ZVV, for instance, doesn't actually operate transport services or send ticket inspectors out - that's done by its member companies (SBB, VBZ, VBG, SZU, BDWM, etc). What the ZVV(/Unireso/TNW/Ostwind/etc) does is act as a coordinating body to make it transparent to the passenger what company operates their buses, arranges it so you can transfer between services operated by different companies without having to pay again, and so on.    
At a higher level, a lot of bus services and all rail services are coordinated and timetabled nationally, producing the somewhat epic three-volume Kursbuch every year (volume 1 railways/ships/cable cars, volumes 2+3 buses) that lays out pretty much all the public transport in the country that isn't part of a town's local bus network.   
A basic function of the tariff union is to deliver cross-medium season tickets ("mobility pass" is the current hip term) like the original poster describes. In more rural areas where there might be only one or two transport operators (say, PostAuto running buses and a regional railway operator like the MGB or RhB) I'm guessing the choice is either a season ticket for the individual operator or a GA.   
It's not an exclusively Swiss setup - there are similiar unified tariff systems elsewhere, either on a regional basis (Germany has many regional tariff unions) or a national one (the Dutch Nationale Strippenkaart comes to mind). Unfortunately the UK is kind of behind the times here. Quelle surprise.

When you queue up to pay the toll, not only you must avoid the yellow-marked "Telepass" lane, but also the lanes for "Viacard" only. Viacard is a prepaid card.   
Stick to the lanes marked for cash payments (the sign has a logo with banknotes and coins). However if you end up in a viacard only lane it's not too bad, because there you can pay with you credit card.   
There is no general rule to where are the different telepass/viacard lanes, sometimes on the left, sometimes on the right, just follow the signs for cash payment.   
In some parts of motorway (for instance around Milano) you must pay before you enter, in this case you will not receive a ticket at the toll booth but you'll be asked for a couple of .   
Be more careful than usual while driving in Italy.   
The general limit on the motorway is 130 km/h. Nobody goes so slow in Italy except huge lorries and swiss pensioners    
The law allows the motorways with three lanes to have 150 km/h limit, but afaik no motorway manager dared to increase the limit to 150 yet.   
In case of rain the limit drops to 110, and in case of fog it's 50 km/h on all the roads (including motorway).

That's what the law says:   An immigrant's household effects are admitted duty-free. The household effects must be imported close to the time when the transfer of domicile occurs, generally in 18 months. I asked the Customs and they said that they will calculate it from the date of entry as stated on your permit.  
You can of course try to claim that you are only now transferring the domicile but I'm not sure how this would work if you have in fact been living and working in Switzerland for 10 years.. 
There is an option to import a car tax free if you have been a resident of Switzerland but worked abroad for at least one year witough giving up the Swiss domicile and used the car there at least 6 months, but in this case you would actually have to show that you were studying and working abroad for a year.

I am sure that the ethics will not be satisfacatory for every one but this might be a solution for some.   
This could be useful if you are going to be in Switzerland for a couple of years and saves: 
(a) Hassle of registering the car in Switzerland 
(b) Re-registering the car in the UK on return which always makes selling the car more difficult as V55 will disclose the export/import of the vehicle. 
(c) Cost of modifying the car to pass Swiss MOT (Head lights for Right Hand Drive) and then changing back for UK on return. 
(d) Car Insurance appears to be cheaper in the UK than Switzerland. 
(e) less likely to be fined for speeding (certainly by cameras) and parking offensives in Switzerland.     
1) Form an English Ltd company. Cost £100 with obviously registered office in England.   
2) Register the vehicle with DVLA in the name of the limited company you want to drive in Switzerland.   
3) Take out car insurance in the UK in the name of the Ltd company and make sure that you are a named driver on the policy and the policy covers travel abroad.  It is better that you also have a UK resident on the insurance policy as a named driver.

Tageskarten which get given out by your gemeinde: the Gemeinde-Tageskarte. As far as I understand it, the gemeinde can order a number of sets of day tickets (one per day per pack) as described here:     
... and then they resell them on to either residents or both residents and non-residents, whichever they choose to do. Validity is basically that of a normal Tageskarte zum Halbtax (in other words, it's a one-day GA) - except you don't need a 1/2 abo to get one. It's actually the only way to get a Tageskarte if you don't have a halbtax, with the exception of a few special offers which appear now and then.   
Many gemeinden manage theirs through the web, often via:     
but others merely sell them over the counter on a first-come, first-served basis. For instance, if you live in the Stadt Zürich you can get them for Fr42,- from the Evergreens kiosk near the Hbf:   
(in Zürich you don't need to be a resident to buy them, which is a top tip for people with visitors who want to go on day trips)   
The number of tickets available is restricted depending on how many sets of tickets the gemeinde has purchased. Oh yeah, and they're second class only,  but they're also upgradable to first via a Tagesklassenwechsel (Fr39,-, or 33,- if it's after 0900) or by paying the upgrade fee for part of the trip if that's what you'd prefer.

You can take the tests in English in Bern.  At least I was able to take the Sailing test, License D, in Bern, in English.   
If you do this it will cost you extra money.   
Your canton will charge you 30chf to send a letter to Bern to tell them that you are registered to take that test.   
Then Bern will charge you 40chf to put you into their system so that you can actually take the test. 
Plus of course you will pay the appropriate fees to actually take the tests as well.   
So in summation, it cost me 70chf more to take the test in English in Bern than it would have to take it in Vaud.  Obviously, plus the cost of travel as well.   
They may charge you individually for each "authorisation" to take the exam at the local canton level, but I think you should only have to pay the administration fee in Bern once.  Of course, I could be wrong, I am just guessing about this last part as I only took one test.      
Good Luck, 
Brian.

TCS are a mobile organisation, so they should be able to do an on-site check. 
The car will have a build up of carbon if it is not used much, driven badly ( as in not revving it high enough) or doing only or a lot of town driving. 
It is normal to race a car down the highway in 3rd or 4th gear to 'clean out' the engine before taking it for the emissions test.   
But of course no-one except the current owner knows about this car. 
Check the service history and the oil level in the car. Talk with the current owner and ask him questions like how much oil he has put in it between services etc. Buying a second hand car is always a gamble, so all you can do is try to minimise your risk.   
By the sounds of it, this is not an old car if you are asking about changing the timing belt when the car reaches 50KM, therefore it should be near perfect.   
If it is sounds all right, looks all right and there are no alarms ringing in your head about the car or the owner, it probably is all right. 
Sometimes you just have to hold onto your balls and take the plunge!  
If there is any reasonable doubt, then get a second opinion or look elsewhere. 
The world is full of second hand cars, no one is twisting your arm.

As the other posters suggested, go to the travel office to get precise prices worked out and information.   
However, here is my 2 Rappen worth:   
As Zürich and Winti are both within ZVV you cannot get strict train tickets. All tickets are automatically also valid within their zones for all public transport. Therefore a ticket from your local bus stop in Winti to your local tram stop in Zürich and including the train and everything in between will cost exactly the same (and in fact be exactly the same ticket in all respects) as the train ticket you would buy from Winterthur Hauptbahnhof to Zürich Hauptbahnhof. A lot of people misunderstand this and end up spending too much.   
If you are only travelling occasionally, you could also consider getting 6-er pack tickets (can't remember the name, Mehrfahrtenkarte maybe?) which you stamp at the ticket machine and which is then valid for one trip or for a given period (for example 1 day, depending on the ticket type, that type is called Tageswahlkarte). You can stamp/use that ticket six times and this often comes cheaper than buying six equivalent tickets individually. You can also conmbine it with a Halbtax which should save you a lot of money if you use it frequently.   
Another option is to get a monthly ticket for Zürich (remember to tell them you are a student as this can get you a reduction) and then get Anschlussbillette for the rare occasions you go to Winterthur. Anschlussbillette are also available in the 6-er format to stamp. An Anschlussbillet is basically an upgrade that tansforms your all Zürich ZVV pass to a Zürich and Winterthur pass for a limited period of time, and again comes cheaper than buying it as a separate ticket.

Usually, there are only complains or bad experiences ending up here (and I am no exception).   
I recently had a great experience with a Swiss insurance and think it is worth to be shared as well:   
I went back to Germany for Christmas at my parents by car. When we wanted to leave again for Switzerland on the 26th, my car started to vibrate and got very noisy. I told myself that it might be a bad idea to drive 400km like this. I somehow remembered that my insurance guy talked me into some extras and that "EU wide help in case of a breakdown" was part of it.   
I called the call center, did not wait for a second in a cablecom-like system, but immediately had an operator who took my details, was friendly and competent and promised me that a local breakdown service would call me within 15 mins to check how bad it was. I was waiting for twenty minutes and just when I was about to get annoyed that nobody called yet, the service car showed up without a prior call. 
The guy needed only five minutes to find out that I had some ignition problems and realy should not drive this far or risk to **** up my engine. I called the insurance and told them the story. They arranged with the service guy a rental car and within less than an hour, I was back on the road. On a holiday. 
My car was pulled to the next Audi center. The next working day, the insurance called me again and kept me updated, that the Audi center would need another day before they had time to look at my car and that the insurance has prolonged the rental car contract for me. One day later, I knew how long it would take and how much it was and the insurance made me the offer to choose: Either drive the rental car back myself to pick up my car (which was the faster solution) or let them tow my car to Switzerland in case I would prefer to get it repaired here. I drove myself as I did want my car back as fast as possible. The insurance did cover all towing and rental car costs.   
All in all a perfect service, competent, pro-active, friendly and very fast. I will stay with Allianz Suisse for sure.

Looks to me like the key point here is that Snow'n'Rail tickets have the rail fare portion discounted at 30% (according to the web). Let's check this out given a sample fare from Zürich HB to Davos Platz:   
Return fare (2. Class) - Fr51.00 with halbtax, Fr102.00 without. 
Snow'n'Rail fare (2. Class) - Fr89.40 with halbtax, Fr125.00 without.   
Looking at the fare differentials, this suggests that the rail fare portion is Fr35.60 each way, which matches the 30% discount. That would *probably* be hard to beat, but looking at the fare from somewhere on the fringes of the ZVV, say, Pfäffikon SZ - Fr41/82 (with/without 1/2 abo). Fr10 difference relative to the fare from Zürich means it'd only be worth doing if you were going to travel more than 5 zones across the ZVV to get there.   
The deciding part is probably that if you're on a journey that crosses the boundary of the ZVV or another fare union and plan to use two tickets to cover this, the ZVV (TNW, etc) ticket is only valid as far as the last *timetabled stop* within the ZVV area for the train you're taking. So for instance, if you're travelling from Zürich-Davos via Landquart, you'll need a ticket from Zürich HB anyway if you're on an IC as the first stop is Sargans. Take an IR and the last stop in the ZVV is Pfäffikon.

post:
I suspect the differences in experiences are related to:   
whether car : 
1 - imported as household goods 
2 - owned at least six months prior to import 
3 - is an "old timer"     
and more importantly whether customs and SCN (registration & testing) offices have been asked for their advice before the event.    
Customs will specify the above and then scn will give you a check list of things to do to make the car comply.   
The check list of compliance items is fundamental to the ensuing experience - for example whether noise and emissions have to be complied with OR NOT (so very basic dramatic differences). Likewise constructors certificate of construction, or not.   
Follow the process is the right advice and check with the authorities BEFORE each step and do it in very good time. There are deadlines (such as 18 months for import of household goods declarations), but they seem reasonable.   
Switzerland in my experience so far is that one simply must ask the officials all along the way and they are helpful and patient, especially with my french.   
Snippet: Trailers have to be metriculated too and get their own reg number.   
The german names will be different.

I remember ten years ago standing in a coffee shop and a parking inspector came in and said "does anyone in here own that red car across the street". Since I had just arrived from Australia I was taken aback at this very tolerant attitude, as Australian parking inspectors had a reputation for being complete bast***s.    
However, I've had it on good authority from several people that nice friendly parking inspectors in London now exist only in my warm fuzzy memories. A few weeks ago I was in Sydney and saw a parking inspector printing me a ticket. I walked up to my car and sarcasticly said "thanks", not expecting much in the way of sympathy. To my utter surprise he apologised profusely, explained that he had been there waiting for me to come back, and if I'd just waved to him as I had approached he could have avoided hitting the print button. I test drove an Insight today. The biggest gripe I had with it was that the guy from the garage came along so the whole drive felt like a driving exam. Just because of this I will make a second testdrive with a car from a different garage...   
I am interested in the car cause it has a cvt transmission,  I don't really care about it being a hybrid. I found it drove like a normal car, I didn't notice any of the technology like swapping between engines and stuff like that. Acceleration in town was good, ride comfort was also good.   
The one thing I didn't like was that accelerating onto the autobahn the thing was screaming its head off at 6000 rpm ! And the noise was really loud. Up to speed it was OK again and everything quieted down again. Minot gripes were that it felt like a big car, not very nimble even though the weight is not big (less than 1300 kg). Maybe this was because the steering was rather heavy. Also I could put the steering all the way up as I would have liked, it blocked my view of the speedo.   
I am still waiting for a testdrive in a diesel VW polo with DSG. The DSG is not a cvt, I am hoping the changing gear will not be annoying to me as I am a big cvt fan (love my GF's old fiat punto and my dads B170, both have cvt)...    
All in all I am having a hard time finding a nice car for around 30000 chf, there's always something wrong with them...

And why do we have courts ?  in a world where you break the law you get punished, what is the point of sentencing guidelines.  because in a world where you absolutely get the punishment for breaking the law there wouldnt be people let off for first offences because your saying its the law, take the ticket (or sentence). A good point to remember here too is that if you do buy the pass in advance, you'll get a money-off voucher for any equipment hiring you need to do at Intersport.

The oyster card is more like a pre-paid phone card, only smarter. You can travel most everywhere, and the fare gets deducted for every trip up to a daily limit. It's nice, I have two for the occasional trip to London.   
Our CH "travel cards" are not much like this. It's a card you purchase (pre-pay) for a certain time period (1 day, week, month, year), for a certain "zone" or for travel between two defined points.  
This is usually a good deal if you use it to go to work for example, 5 days a week. Any less and you may want to consider buying your tickets from the machines at any station as needed.   
Halb-tax (Half-fare) cards are usually nice to have if you travel often between cities. See sbb.ch for all the details in English. 
http://mct.sbb.ch/mct/en/reisemarkt/...te/halbtax.htm 
After a few trips to St Moritz or Zermatt, the card pays for itself.   
I'm sure if you search the EF, you will find a few references on this subject.

You will not be asked for any documents until the Swiss border ... and depending on the style of van, perhaps not even then. But as the law is written, you should stop at Swiss customs and present documents; the easiest way is to hire a customs broker to post a bond for you and then you continue on your way and your customer provides passport and visa information and signs a claim (if entitled) to duty-free entry.   
I use man-and-a-van enterprises from time to time, and on one occasion in each direction I have used professional movers. The man-and-a-van tends not to file papers. The professional movers do it right and send me the documents by overnight post for completion and filing. (The transport in each case is between London and Valais or Geneva.)   
I have never been asked to pay anything by Swiss customs when bringing in stuff in my car, although once or twice (since I have a Swiss passport and UK plates on my car) I have been asked for evidence that I live in the UK.   
Hope that helps.

Because SBB fares are calculated from station to station whereas "Verkehrsverbund" or "Tarifverbund" fares are calculated on the basis of zones.   
Those are two fundamentally different ways of calculating prices.   
So, to re-use NotAllThere's example.   
The SBB fare from Basel to Bern is the price from Basel SBB station to Bern station. That ticket is valid on any reasonable service by any reasonable route between those two stations.   
Equally, the SBB ticket from Liestal to Bern is valid on any reasonable service by any reasonable route between those two stations.   
Now if you have an Abo that covers the zones of Basel SBB, Liestal and whatever there is in between, you can travel from any place in those zones to any other place in those zones. You can, for example, travel from Basel SBB to Liestal. Then in Liestal you can catch a train to Bern. If the train you used to come to Liestal continues to Bern you can even hop straight back onto that same train and into the same seat you were in before. Only you have ended one trip and begun the next by putting one foot outside the train. Now, rather then be pedantic and demand you put one foor outside the train, SBB says it is sufficient that the train has stopped and that you could have put one foot outside the train.

You can bring your car with you as personal effect and use it with American plates up to 1 or 2 years (not sure which). You don't need to do any administration. It's as if you just drove it here.   
But, even if you import one for Swiss registration from day one you are still BETTER off than buying here. 
In that case you have to pay 4% import tax and 7.6% VAT a.k.a. sales tax. 
So all in all you are looking at a 12% premium on top of the US price. 
I give you an example: 
BMW 335i, US retail $40,000 
BMW 335i, Swiss retail 64k CHF = $59,000 
Even if you add the %12 import tax and shipping you are still saving around $10k.   
Plus, when you go back to the US and still have the car it's easy to bring it back and register it (being US spec model).     
just my 2c

One of the open questions is if Switzerland will start with points and agree a points exchange program.   
It's all part of the EU driving license program to gradually exchange more and more info beyond just recognizing each others licenses. Even within the EU this is being done bilaterally for legal reasons.  
One of the issues is the multiple still valid versions of licenses per country (there's a document on it on the EU website).  
Another is the lack of consistency of points offences and fines for the same offences (see the table the TCS/DAS produces each summer).  
Finally the EU realises it needs to recognize bans EU wide as it's still legal after a ban to pass a driving test in another EU state and drive back home without going through special arrangements applicable in your home state (like in Germany).  
This is also possible as the rules on residency to qualify for license testing/issuance are light. In addition exchanging can clean your record from another state's point of view.   
I agree with the pragmatic motivation mentioned earlier for the Swiss probably best summarised as: "Gibts geld?....OK".

You weren't duped. You are a grown-up. Take responsibility and shop around.

Let me insert my 5 cents.   
People tend to buy cars at dealer shops because the reparation fees in CH are quite expensive. So its better to take car with insurance of 3 month and be relaxed for that time. However, in this case you overpay some extra money as-well.   
Normally, cars in CH are good. Because of strict rules and strict fines (people tend to drive maximum 120 km per h and this saves the engine, as it is not rotated that high), strict expertise (MFK) and all those tests like antipollution, etc. So, if the car has antipollution sticker, it passed expertise, its kilometrage is not above 120K it is a good deal even at private person. Special moments to pay attention when buying at private person:   
1)	Make sure it is not Yugoslavian guy (I do not judge usually by nation, but I have met multiple cases when yougoslavians tried to fool me and my friends; mostly buying BMWs)   
2)	Ask guy when it was serviced and ask clarification  bills, reports; if the guy has difficulties to answer when oil was changed, cancel the deal   
3)	Ask when distribution belt was changed. This is quite critical part of the engine, as on 16v engines the break of belt causes damages of valves. The change is quite costly as well, it is hard to change yourself, and in garage they will ask over 1000CHF for that. So better to make sure it is changed before. Get bills and check if possible. (P.S. All BMW from 2.0L and higher has the distribution chain, which is not breaking, but it can also be probablematic because of extra long shifts in chain, so listen the sound of engine : ) )   
4)	Check the underground part, more specifically the isolation of Constant-velocity joint ( )  this applies only for front wheel cars. If isolation is damaged, the unit might be damaged with dust and water, and it will pass away soon  It is also expensive. At expertise (MFK) they do not check that, i.e., if isolation is broken they do not fail expertise. So keep an eye on it.   
5)	Ask if guy has winter tyres, etc. Usually car is sold with two set of tyres. If there is no second set, this is a reason to ask to lower the price.   
If any of the above is met, this is a way to ask the price to go lower; or even a good reason to visit garage to make detailed investigation of car and its potential problems.

post: Since you have been living in Switzerland for more than 12 months your Indian licence is no longer valid for driving in Switzerland and you can't convert it to a Swiss licence. In order to get a Swiss licence you will have to pass the Swiss driving test. Even if you apply for an International Driving Permit, this will not allow you to drive in Switzerland because the IDP is only valid here if your Indian licence is valid in Switzerland - which it isn't. All an IDP does is translate and certify the validity of your Indian licence and isn't valid licence on it's own.  I can't help on whether your indian licence on it's own would be valid for driving in all other european countries (though I can't see why it shouldn't be if it hasn't expired) or whether you would need an IDP in conjunction with your indian permit.

You need to be domiciled in Switzerland, otherwise the seller is selling to a non-resident that lives in another country, and thus is exporting the car   
You need to have insurance to get the licence plates, which are issued to the owner, and not to the vehicle. ie: the seller keeps his licence plates, and you fit yours. No insurance = no plates. 
To get insurance you need to be domiciled / live in Switzerland   
So first come here, get properly registered and domiciled, then it is easy to buy a car.

As I understand it, children in Switzerland don't begin school until they are 6.  Before that, they attend a krippe or kindergarten.  I don't know whether your son would be eligible to attend a Swiss kindergarten or school if you live in Germany but I'm fairly certain it's possible.  A colleague of mine's son attends school in Basel and he and his family live across the border.  I know that there is a krippe close to Feldbergstrasse - maybe you could drop your son off there on the way to work each day and there must be plenty of others on this tram route. A few tips for moving by airplane:     1. Appliance adaptors, particularly laptop and chargers weight a lot. Carry these in your in your coat pockets. This keeps your hand luggage weight down.      2. Step on the end of the baggage scale. This counter balances the weight and your bag weigh less. Only works for check-in desks that weigh the bag on the end closest to you. Some airlines are getting smart and moving the scale back, so they move your bag about a meter before weighing it.     3. Have a friend keep another bag or two away from the check-in desk.  Use duty free bags from previous trips. Looks like you went shopping on the way to the flight      4. Carry any books you want to bring in their own carry bag. You are normally allowed an un-specified amount of reading material for the journey.   
5. This is really cheeky   - use your children's allowance. Pack items in a pushchair box - this is not part of your luggage allowance.

I recently took my Audi A4 (54,000 miles) to a dealer. within the last year, I have had the steering rack and pinion, a water pump, 4 coils replaced. this time I simply wanted a new Dipstick as it had disintegrated and could potential send parts through the engine. 
Audi replaced the dipstick and holder and then asked me to sign a peice of paper. they said that they had done a free inspection of the timing belt and found that it had cracks, that I must pay for replacement, otherwise all other warranties on the car were void. 
I was surprised I thought that a timing belt should last for about 80-100,000 miles as stated in the owner manual.    
What had happened is that woman's timing belt had broken at around 40,000, prompting a class action law suit. To cover themselves all Audi have to do is to give a free inspection, even if not requested, when you bring the car in for any other reason. They can then say that they alerted you and they are not responsible.   
We are fighting this legally, the timing belt will be taken out today, tested and compared.   
I would advise everyone to refuse 'free inspections'.

1) The swiss Police can not, under any circumstances, take away or ask you to hand over your australian drivers licence. BUT they can ban you from driving around in switzerland. So if you were found to be driving around you would be charged as if your license had been revoked.   
2) If fines reach a certain amount, they automatically go before the court, where you can be fined extra. 850.- is almost certainly a fine that would go before courts. What can happen (with a swiss licence) that the police takes away the license on the spot and courts then decide how long you will have to wait for it or extra fines (depending on your 'criminal' history or on the severity of the transgression.   
3) From my understanding the driving ban begins either immediatley after the incident or after the court's ruling. Since the policeman didnt inform you of any immediate consequences I would assume it's the latter. So three months after the ruling, your australian license should once more be recognized by swiss authorities - that is if you have paid the 150.- extra fine.   
Hope this helps.

Not here in Switzerland obviously, but if I went home I would still drive my parents car or rent a car yes. There is no reciprocal agreement between Ireland and Switzerland and my ban would be in Switzerland on my Swiss licence. Of course if I drove in Switzerland or a Swiss registered car I would be in a world of sh!t, but across the border I am not banned.   
This happens all the time. Germans who get caught excessively speeding in Switzerland or Austria or escorted to the border or have a passenger drive them to the border then they are free to drive from there. There is usually a clause on their fine that they cannot drive for x amount of time in the country they were caught in.    
There was also the publicised case of Jay Kay a few years back where he was banned from driving in France (and Switzerland I think), but he could happily tootle around in his Lambo back in the UK or Germany because the driving ban did not extend across the border. Same thing happens with the cannonball drivers and those guys in the supercars who were caught in Zurich earlier in the year. The get the full brunt of the authorities here, but they still have not committed a crime outside of Switzerland. They can be banned from driving in Switzerland but not anywhere else.    
If you only have a Swiss licence and you are banned in Switzerland then tough, you do not have valid licence. But if you have a licence valid for another jurasticion the ban applies to your Swiss licence and driving in Switzerland (and for insurance reason driving Swiss cars anywhere). But if you own a car in your home country then whats to stop you driving there. Remember the stamp on the licence is "Not valid in Switzerland" so they have no control of what you do with that licence or in another country.

Hi An Luan,   
Yes, you might be in for some fun... We've covered this topic before - in quite a bit of detail. please use the search function and you'll find some useful information.

Here's the link on the SBB regarding the Power Point spots in Business compartments (1st class) and which trains generally have them.         
On the outside of the train near the door - you will see this symbol telling you if that compartment has such power sockets - note, though, even with this symbol, not all seats in that compartment have their own socket:

There is a distance restriction of around 70km. If the trip is below this length then the return portion is only valid on the date of purchase, if it is beyond this length then the return portion is valid for one month. But, as Keith said, this should be printed on the ticket somewhere.    
The reason for the one day validity is to avoid people doing what you are trying to do - missing the ticket agent the first time and using the ticket again on another day. This is more likely to happen on shorter trips, which is why there is a distance cut-off.

It seems that Biofuel may just be a temporary solution and only take a small percentage of the market. As grain prices increase, there is much debate as to whether it is appropriate to use land to grow corn etc. for fuel.   
In the UK the price of cooking oil has recently jumped in price to match the increases in diesel prices. The large savings that were available have generally disappeared.   
The same is likely to happen with waste oil as more companies see it as a commodity rather than a waste product.   
It is possible to run a diesel car on clean cooking oil, though it is not recommended. It is thicker than diesel and doesn't have the various additives to protect the engine. The most common problem is blocked injectors. There have been cases of people filtering waste oil and using that in their cars, often with expensive bills to follow.   
It has been more successful to mix clean oil with diesel 50/50 but the cost savings are negligible with the risk of higher maintenance bills   
Unless research comes up with an alternative production source, it is likely to remain a minority fuel.

Hmmm, I would definitely try to get a second opinion if I were you. Towing the car home could be an option but then you'd need to see if you could get a tame greasemonkey to come out to you for a look. 
I used to "odd job" work at a local repair garage as I wanted to learn enough about cars to keep my old classic on the road and base the following comments on my own experiences:   
The overheating could have caused a warped cylinder head but it might not be all that bad. It could be simply be a "blown" i.e. leaking cylinder head gasket. Bern's comments ref Mayonaisse are absolutely correct - also check for oily film on top of the water in the reservoir or radiator. Ideally, if you can't get a mechanic's 2nd opinion, get yourself a cylinder pressure gauge and check the cylinder pressures. That still won't tell you for certain if the problem is hte head or the gasket - to properly check the head it will need to be removed and properly measured.    
If you're not bothered about matching body/engine numbers in the car then you could consider swapping the engine - it's often far less work to swap an engine than it is to strip an engine in situ, repair and re-assemble. 
Good luck :-)

I too was very familiar with the process of taking over a lease from my time in the USA and was interested to do the same here. But it was non-starter. I could hardly find any used cars that offered a lease - unlike the USA which has a very attractive and huge secondary market for leased cars, everytime I asked here I got blank stares.   
You are right that leases are more expensive here than in the USA. It seems there is neither the volume nor the subsidies provided by the car makers to move certain models.   
In the end, I bought a used car and financed it with a relatively inexpensive bank loan. Overall, the payments are much higher than a lease would have been for an equivalent car in the USA. Of course that is because I am financing the entire purchase and not simply the amount borrowed.    
From a financial point of view, your best bet is probably to buy a used car. There are many used cars available and the prices seem quite competitive (i.e. a 1 year old car is about 20% less than the new model).

Its actually benificial to rather get your International license from your original country (issued in yr original country to you), and then to come here and drive a few months with an International License. I am not sure if it depends on country-country, but I was issued with a one year International License (South Africa) and that you can obviously drive her ein Switzerland for one year with. before the year is over, you have to convert that license into a Swiss license.   
You have to go to your license authority (swiss) and book an appointment, they will send you a letter stating the time and date of yr driving test. And...a few thinsg that you have to bring with for example...a stamped/signed eye test from a swiss optometrist. But the eye test is easy, walk into any optometrist and give them the paper that the license authority send to you, and they complete it and stamp it and also do a quick test. Does not cost much as far as I can remember. Also you need ID pics etc etc. Nothing strange there I guess in what you needed.   
So, here is yr questions to yr answer:l 
1) I think THINK you can drive 1 yr with a valid issued AA license, BUT..check on yr AA issued license or otherwise rather make sure and take a drive to yr local license authority. Its worth it, you do not want to end up on the wrong side of these things. 
2) Yes, you have to give an eye test paper in, one that they would send you to have stamped and completed 
3) I did not have to do a written exam/ test before the actual driving test. I think it might depend on yr AA license, and where you coem from...but I do not think that the US would be a problem. 
4) Look at my answer at top, I think its beneficial. Especially good that you get to know the rules and roadsigns.    
What I did, I took a friend with me to drive, and she woudl play the authority and direct me in driving where and when, and we drove around where the licensing place were...as you start obviously at license office and then have to go somewhere...so, take a drive there, ...on a quiet day, and just drive and test yourself, and notice things and check it out.    
But, from all the posts here...you can read that most say that you should spend yr money and go and get a instructor to drive with you. TRUE...do that, its money worth spending, rather than to THINK you have th rule right, and then later are sorry to find out that the Swiss treats teh rule different etc.   
Do not panic to much, I promise you also...if you are a confident driver and know your car and drive well, without any false starts and beginner things...that also helps. be confident, and try to be calm, he is only there to see if you CAN actually drive a car, obey rules and are not a hooligan on the road and will NOT endanger anyone. So, good luck, be yourself. When I got in teh car with teh authority, he told me very nicely that I should just drive like ai drive everyday and relax, as he is only looking if I can handle my car, the rules and be on the road legally! I hope that you also get a nice guy..

Glad that you were not injured!   
There is no point system in Switzerland. The vignette will cover the car damage but not your bike and the ambulance. It's up to the police if/how this case proceeds (I estimate, not far) but the fine for crossing a red light on the bicycle is 60 Fr..   
Some insurers have a form on their website that you can use to report the accident. If you have a copy of the accident protocol (Unfallprotokoll), the insurers may be interested in it too.     's a leaflet in German about what to do in a bicycle accident (PDF) (also valid for other traffic accidents). The most important points are to fill out an accident protocol if there's property damage, and to call the police if somebody got injured, which only then is mandatory.

It certainly sounds like you need a floor pump / track pump. I recently got a new one, and went with one made by Park Tools because all their stuff is great, it is the  .    
A couple of months later, I was talking to a guy who helps out at a bicycle recyclery in the US. They needed some new pumps, and so decided to buy one of the consumer-level floor pumps from each major manufacturer. They each took a similar wheel and one of the new pumps, then pumped in synchrony to see which pumped got up to the desired pressure the fastest and with fewest pumps. They switched the pumps around, then repeated the task. Plus, they tried with mountain and road tyres, and different valve type. They also each rated the pumps on more subjective criteria, and then tallied all of the scores up. Apparently, the Park Tools PFP-3 won the contest, and there was only one other competitor that came close to its score (but I can't remember which it was).   
Therefore, it's not only my bias towards Park Tools that makes me recommend this one, but there is also reasonable solid empirical evidence that its the best thing for the job. You can get one from   for 54 CHF. You may be able to get a different model for a little cheaper, maybe 35-40 CHF if you search hard enough, but I don't think it would be worth it, just go for the Park Tools version.

Its almost certainly a scam. We check scams for Auto Trader via   and this is a well established one.    
The vendor offers a car which is priced far too low. The story is usually similar  - he or she is a foreing nations who worked in Britain - usually in the City and bought a (usually expensive) right hand drive car. Subsequently their employer recalled them home. They drove the car back to Spain/Italy/Switzerland (fill in blank) but couldn't get on with it driving on the right, but dealers would offer little for it. They now wanted rid of it but the local dealers would pay very little. They don't have time to drive it back to sell it in the UK.   
They are contacted by buyers in the UK, one of which will fall for the story. They will then offer to put you in touch with their "shipper" who will deliver the car. The idea is the buyer pays the "shipper" before delivery who holds the funds in Escrow, releasing them only to the seller when the car arrives. The shipper usually has a fairly impressive website and possibly a call centre.    
The problem is that the vendor and the shipper are in cahoots (may be the same person) and once the buyer pays everyone disappears leaving the buyer having paid the money without any car.   
I can list you numerous "shippers" who we have recorded operating this scam but there is little point - as soon as one closes another one opens up.   
If he plans to buy the car he should tell them he will not unless he checks out the vehicle, verifies the seller has clear title to it, pays for it by a recognised means within a secure environment and brings the vehicle home with him.   
If the deal provides for anything other than this he should not get involved or he is likely to lose a great deal of money rather than save it.

I have found this way to be the most convenient for driving from Zurich to Lugano:   
- Drive on the A1 towards Bern (trust me) 
- At the Limmattal Kreuz follow for Urdorf 
- You'll be left near Affoltern Am Albis. Follow the blue signs towards Zug/Luzern 
- When you arrive in Steinhausen you'll find green signs 
- Get on the highway and drive towards Schwyz/Brunnen/Gotthard, NOT Luzern 
- At the end of the first stretch of highway do the Axenstrasse and get back on the A2 in Flüelen 
- Continue south towards the Gotthard   
With this little trick you save some good km, you avoid the Sihlstrasse and the traffic around Luzern. Additionally you save yourself the trouble of speed cameras on the S.Bernardino and the annoying 80km limit around Luzern, but be careful on the normal road between Affoltern a.A. and Steinhausen, there's a couple there.   
If you want to do the same on the way back, remember to exit the A2 in Flüelen, follow the Axenstrasse, highway from Brunnen and then exit in Cham. If you miss the exit and go through to Zug, you'll end in the Sihlstrasse, so you're not lost forever.

Just to get this right, you are fully entitled to drive in the UK and it is not an offence to hire a car there. There is no misrepresentation or fraud involved in the hiring of a car as you are not banned from driving outside of Switzerland or Lichtenstein.   
However, you would of course need a valid license from somewhere as the rules of driving in the UK states that the driver must have a license valid for the category of vehicle they are driving. If you just so happen to have another driving license then you can use that entirely legally.   
At the moment no country can enforce a driving ban outside of its area of  jurisdiction.

So here is how the calculation goes: 
200 CHF (price of car) (TCS actully used 320 on a car costing initially 32000 CHF) 
120 CHF (garage) =>average used by TCS, much higher in a city could be lower in the country side 
150 CHF (fuel) considering an average 15000 km a year (which is not very much these days) 
35 CHF (circulation tax) 
125 CHF (RC & Casco) 
150 CHF (maintenanance) 
Total= 780 CHF   
Of course you may have cheaper insurance, leave the car in the street, not change your tires, drive less etc etc, but this is indeed the average cost.... and... without calculating the potential money you could make if you were to invest the money you put into the car in the first place for the 6-7 years you keep the car... so, a car is indeed an expensive thing

The situation in canton Zurich is a bit complicated because every transport company of the ZVV organisation has different rules. You can find the   in German.   
 If you transport the bicycle only inside the ZVV system, you have to buy your ticket a second time. If you have a half fare card (Halbtax), the bicycle only requires a half fare ticket, too. If you leave the ZVV territory during the bicycle transport, or if the second ticket costs more than 15 Fr. (10 Fr. with half fare), you should buy the normal train-compatible day pass for the bicycle, which is valid on ZVV lines, too.   
 You can transport your bicycle in the trams if there is enough space left for the other passengers (this applies for all ZVV member companies that allow bicycle transports). All ships on Lake Zurich except the small Limmatschiff allow bicycles. The Horgen-Meilen ferry accepts bicycles, too, it costs just 3 Fr., cyclist included. In double-decker trains (S-Bahn),  bicycle transports are allowed except Mo-Fr 6-8am and 4-7pm.

As it is holiday season, just a quick note that may save you a blow out on the mototway back to  .   
If you have tyres that are more than ten years old (see explanation below) you should replace them. Your tyres may not be as new as you thought...   
All tyres should have a DOT (from US Department of Transport) manufacture date with the week number and year on them.   
For example, a tyre manufactured in week 40 of 2006 would have a DOT four digit value of 4006 (JAB4006 in the example below) JAB is an internal manufacturer code I believe.       
If your tyres are old and you need to replace them, pay attention to the DOT date of the "new tyres" you buy.   
Perhaps another thread, all tyres   be of the same type for the expertise (MOT).   
If they are older than two years it is recommended that you do not accept them. If you are happy to buy them then you should ask for a large reduction!   
Source:  (in French)   
Happy motoring

The Lötschberg base tunnel is virtually complete. Although regular passenger train service will not start until the new timetables are brought in on December 9th, 2007, there is going to be an opening festival on June 16th, 2007. Every half hour throughout the day, there will be passenger trains travelling through the 35 km (21 miles) long tunnel from Frutigen, in Bern, to Visp, in Valais / Wallis. For a 5 CHF reservation fee plus the cost of the normal train ticket, you can get yourself a place on one of these speedy trains. The RailAway site has a page about the opening festival in   or  .    
Websites: 
Lötschberg base tunnel:  ,   on the tunnel breakthrough in 2005.  
BLS AlpTransit (the company building the base tunnels):   and    
The Lötschberg base tunnel (combined with the old Simplon tunnel) is the first of two routes that will allow traffic to pass through the Alps without having to do any significant climbing (the other being the Gotthard base tunnel, see an  , or the  ). The Lötschberg base tunnel will be the longest land tunnel in the world (i.e., that doesn't go under a body of water). The base tunnels are being built to help take most of the European truck traffic off of Swiss roads and put it onto trains.   
So, why not be one of the first to ride through the tunnel on June 16th? You can reserve a place at your local train station; they only started taking reservations on May 1st, and when I made mine this morning, there were still plenty of spaces available. There will be special festivities happening at the stations at both ends (Frutigen and Visp), and the trip through the tunnel could easily be combined with a trip down to   and maybe onto   via a rack railway that will take you to above 3,000m.

Essentially, one third of the fines never get paid and it's too costly to follow up. Usually it's Germans who are not used to the concept of speed limits and if you are from abroad, then it's difficult to track you down. Still, 60% of fines sent to Germans are paid, whereas only roughly a quarter of those expedited to France are settled.   
If you want to see what you might be looking at:     
Consequences to be faced in your case depend on how well the Swiss and British police work together. There are agreements with certain countries to put pressure on people to pay up their bills.   
However, as you massively exceeded the speed limit without being arrested, what may happen is that, should you be in Switzerland and get caught up in a "Verkehrskontrolle", they may see the previous offence and hold you responsible there and then. This has been done in the past, as the archives of the city of Zurich show.   
I presume it is superfluous to say that you shouldn't be speeding in the first place and that any consequence to be faced should not be grumbled at.

Insurance - not sale:   
Swiss drivers aside, I'd say the chances of you hitting an expensive car here are higher than, say, France or UK. 
This means higher repair costs etc, which should surely reflect in premiums.   
I decided on Swiss insurance for my (low value) UK car for my peace of mind. 
Right hand drive car, my inexperience on the wrong side of the road...   
This was also based on advice of my other half (12 years UK insurance work). 
She said not to trust a UK insurer to cough up if something happened... also UK issued green card expense.   
The Swiss vs UK cost was about the same but Swiss cover was better and had a green card, but then I was paying inner city premium in the UK. 
If you're paying Scottish Highlands rates, you're in for a shock...

I don't understand your $550 liability.  That is the policy cost, your own deductable if you claim or what?   
You need to ensure that the 3rd party is fully-covered - there is no "no-fault" law in Swizterland or any of Europe as far as I know.

As for planting more trees etc to off-set carbon use this in itself could have  . It is now thought that the mini-ice age that started back in the 14th Century was caused by the Black Death or plague. You need residency papers to register and insure. A leftover from the late 30's along with Milan Central Station I presume. I understand that new EU laws might make things easier next year where residency in the EU willno longer be able to be restrictive. But not yet.

I would suggest registering it on time restricted import plates for the first 12 months and then officially importing it. This way you remove the need to pay duty and the VAT which is calculated on the present worth will also be reduced. Insurance is more expensive by the way and it therefore will be very dependent on the price difference between the German model and the Swiss one.    
So other suggestions why not try going and looking at EU imported cars on the web. Someone else has then had the headache.
